*310. THE SERIES OF REAL NUMBERS. 
Summary of *310. 
Real numbers, as opposed to ratios, are required primarily in order to 
obtain a Dedekindian series, so as to secure limits to sets of rationals having 
no rational limit. If rationals and irrationals are to form one series, it is 
necessary to give some definition of " rationals" other than " ratios," since 
the series of ratios (assuming the axiom of infinity) is not Dedekindian, and 
is not part of any arithmetically definable Dedekindian series. But in virtue 
of the propositions of *212, the series of segments of the series of ratios, 
i.e. the series $'H, is Dedekindian, and this series contains a series, namely 
H'H, which is ordinally similar to H. Thus the properties which we desire 
real numbers to have will result if we identify them* with segments of H, 
—* 
and give the name " rational real numbers" to segments of the form H'X, 
—* 
i.e. to segments which have ratios as limits. Thus H'X is the rational real 
number corresponding to the ratio X, and a real number in general is of the 
form H"X, where X is a class of ratios. H"X will be irrational when X has 
no limit or maximum in H. 
Since real numbers involve classes of ratios, the ratios concerned must be 
of some one type, and cannot be typically indefinite. Thus, as might be 
expected, hardly any of the properties of real numbers can be proved without 
assuming the axiom of infinity. In the present number, however, we shall 
be mainly concerned with just those few simple properties which are  
independent of the axiom of infinity. 
The series s'H, by which real numbers are to be defined, has both a 
beginning and an end, namely A and D'H (which = G'H if the axiom of 
infinity holds). D'H will be infinity among real numbers. It is not  
convenient to include it in the series of real numbers as defined, just as it was 
not convenient to include oo q in the series if. or H'. Again A is not 
naturally to be taken as the zero of real numbers, which should rather be 
taken as being i'0q. Thus we are led to the two following definitions, in 
which © is the series of positive real numbers other than zero and infinity, 
* On this definition of real numbers, cf. Principles of Mathematics, Chap. xxxm. 

SECTION A] 
THE SERIES OF REAL NUMBERS 
317 
while ©' is the series of zero and the positive real numbers other than 
infinity: 
«810-01. e >= (s'ff) £ (-i'A - irD'JET) Df 
«810-011. ©' = i% «f © Df 
These notations are framed on the analogy of H and H', the letter © 
being chosen to suggest 8, the relation-number of the continuum. Although 
we do not have Nr'© = 0, we have Nr's'if=#, and therefore (#310-15) 
i + Nr'© + i = 8, and Nr'©' +1 = 0 (assuming the axiom of infinity). Thus 
the relation-number of ® is simply that of a 8 with the ends cut off. 
We put further, on the analogy of Hn, Hg,

«310021. ©'„ = i'0g<f ®„ Df

Thus ®B is the series of negative real numbers, ®'„ the series of zero and 
the negative real numbers, ®? the series of negative and positive real numbers

is C'@, of negative real numbers (?'©„, of all real numbers (excluding infinity)

respect of limits, continuity, etc., result from the properties of 8 as proved in 
*275, and from the properties of series of segments as proved in «212. 
Instead of taking the series of segments as constituting the real numbers, 
it is possible to take the series of their relational sums, i.e. s»®. This 
depends on the fact that s>©smor© (*31033). The chief advantage of 
s>© is that it is of the same type as the series of ratios. We shall show in 
«314 how to construct the arithmetic of real numbers defined as the relational 
sums of segments; until then, we shall regard real numbers as segments of 
the series of ratios.

81(311. ADDITION OF CONCORDANT REAL NUMBERS. 
Summary of *311. 
We define a set of real numbers as concordant when all are positive 
or zero, or all are negative or zero, i.e. when all belong to C'& or all belong 
to G'&n- Given two concordant real numbers ji and v, we define the sum of 
H and v as the class of sums, in the sense of *308, of a member of p and a 
member of v, i.e. as 
fr[(&M,N).Mep.Nev. W=M+gN}, 
i.e. as s'/j, +a"v, in virtue of *40'7. It is easy to prove that, assuming the 
axiom of infinity, the sum so defined has the properties we require of a sum. 
We denote the sum so defined by "fi+pv." In order to insure that fi+pv 
shall be A unless p, v are concordant real numbers, we put 
8)(31102. p+pv=X {concord(/x,v).Xes'fi +g"v] ^f 
Thus if /j,, v are concordant real numbers, (1+,1/= s'/x +g"v (*311"11); if 
not, n+pv = k (*311"1). A definition of addition which applies to real 
numbers of opposite sign will be given in *312. 
The commutative and associative laws for +p (*31112121) follow at 
once from the corresponding laws for +g. Assuming tbe axiom of infinity, 
we prove without much difficulty that the sum of two positive real numbers 
is a positive real number (*311-27), and the sum of two negative real 
numbers is a negative real number (*311'42). In these proofs, when  
propositions of previous numbers involving " Rat " are used, " Rat" is replaced by 
C'H' and " Rat - i'0q " by C'H. This is legitimate in virtue of #3044934. 
In *311'511 we prove (assuming the axiom of infinity) that if f is a positive 
real number, and Y is any positive ratio, however small, there are members 
X of I such that Y+gX is not a member of f, i.e. given any positive real 
number, there are rationals differing from it by less than any assigned positive 
rational. This proposition is useful, and is used in proving that if f, 7? are 
positive real numbers, each is less than f +pr) (*311"52). The converse of this 
proposition, i.e. the proposition that, if fj,®v, tbere is a positive real number 

SECTION A] ADDITION OF CONCORDANT REAL NUMBERS 321 
X such that i/ = /x+pX, is proved in »311*621*64, after a considerable amount 
of work. Thus we have 
«311*65. I-:: Infin ax . D :. /t&v ,= :^,ve G'% : (gX). X e C'% . v - /x +pX 
We have, of course, a corresponding proposition for 6„ (*311*66). From 
«311*65 we deduce without difficulty that if /x is less than v (/x, v being 
positive real numbers), then X +p /i is less than X +p v (X being a positive 
real number), i.e. 
*311*73. h : Infin ax . X e C"6 . /xBi/ . D . (X +p ^) @ (X +p v) 
whence (with the corresponding proposition for ©„) we deduce 
«311*75. V :. Infin ax . concord (X, /x). D : X +p ^ = X +p v. = . /x = v 
which secures the uniqueness of subtraction.

*312. ALGEBRAIC ADDITION OF REAL NUMBERS. 
Summary of *312. 
In this number we extend the definition of addition so as to apply to real 
numbers of opposite sign. As in *308, this requires a previous definition of 
subtraction. We define subtraction as follows: If there is a X such that 
v+pX — fi, then fi —p v is A.; if there is a \ such that /t+fX=i/, then fi—pv is 
| Cnv"\, i.e. the negative of X; in any other case, /i—pv = A. The formal 
definition is : 
#312-01. fi-pv = X {(gA.) :X)fi,ve C'®g: 
v +PX = /j.. X eX.v ./j. +pX = v . X e\ Cnv"X.) Df 
Hence assuming the axiom of infinity we have 
i/(8o8„)/t.D./i-j^ (?X) (v +p X = /t) (#31218), 
/i(t&v1dn)v.'2.p-pv = (l\)(jt+p\Cnv"\ = v) (#312181), 
XeC'®g.O.X-pX = i'0q (#312191). 
The algebraic sum of /j. and v is defined as fi +pv if /j. and v are of the 
same sign, and as fi —p | Cnv"i/ if /j. and v are of opposite signs; i.e. we put 
#312-02. /i+. i» = (/i+,1») «(/*-* I Cnv"i») Df 
This definition is justified because either fi+pv or fi—p\Cnv"v must 
always be A. Thus we have 
#31232. V : concord (/*, v). D . /t +«v = fi +pv 
#312-33. V : ~ concord (/i, v). D. ^ +a v = /j. -v | Cnv"i/ 
The propositions proved are analogous to those of previous numbers, and 
.offer no difficulty. 
#31201. fi-pv = X{(<3X):X,fi,veC'®g: 
v+pX = /j..XeX.v.fi+pX = v.Xe\ Cnv"A.} Df

*313. MULTIPLICATION OF REAL NUMBERS. 
Summary of #313. 
Multiplication of real numbers is simpler than addition, because it is not 
necessary to distinguish between factors of the same sign and factors of 
opposite signs. Thus we put 
«818*01. fixav=-X{(i,veG(%g.Xes'fixg((v} Df 
Thus if fi, v are real numbers, their product is the class of products (in 
the sense of *309) of members of p and members of v; otherwise their product 
is A. The propositions of this number are analogous to those of previous 
numbers, and the proofs are as a rule analogous to those of *311, except in 
the case of the distributive law (#313'55). 
«31301. nxav = X[fi,veC'®g.Xes'fixg"v} Df 
Proofs in this number are mostly analogous to those for addition, and are 
therefore often omitted. 
«313-11. h : ~ O, v e C'@g). D. fi xa v = A 
«313-12. h : fi, v e C'%g. D . /t xa v = s'fi xg"v 
«313-21. h : p, v e C'% u i'i'0q. D . /t xa v = s V x,"v 
«313-22. h : /i, v e C'®n « i'i'0q .3.fi,xav = s'(\ Cnv» x."(| Cnv"i») 
«313-23. \-ipe C'8B . v e C% . D. /t x„ v = | Cnv'Vfl Cnv'V) *>"v 
«313-24. h^O'e.M C'e„. D. /i xB i» - | Cnv"«'(/* x,)"| Cnv"i» 
«313-25. h . /t x„ v = i Cnv"(j Cnv'V x„ i>) = | Onv'V x„ | Cnv"i> 
«313-26. h . /x x„ | Cnv"i/ = | Cnv'V x„i/= | Cnv"(> xai>) 
«818-81. h : Infin ax . f e C<©. Z e (,"#. D. Z x/'f C H"X x/'f 
«313-32. h : Infin ax . f eC© . Ze C'H. D. Z xg"% = H"X xg"g 
«313-33. h : Infin ax . £ e O© . Z e C'iT. D. Z x/'f e C© 
«313-34. h : Infin ax . f e C'©„. Z e C'#n. D. Z x/'f e C© 

334 QUANTITY [PART VI 
#313 35. h : Infin ax . f e C'0 . X eC'Hn . D. Z x/'f eC'©n 
#313 351. h : Infin ax. f eC'0„. X eC'H.D.Ix,"feC'0„

#31341. h : Infin ax . concord (^, i>). /t 4= i'0q . 1/ =(= i'0? .0. /j.xav e C0 
#31342. V : Infin ax . ~ concord (/*, v). /j.,ve C'%g . D. /j. xa v e C'©„ 
^13-43. h :. /u, = t'O, . v . v = i'0q :fi,ve C09 : D. /i xa 1/ = i'0q 
#313 44. h : Infin ax . /t, v e C'%g .D./tx^e C'%g

81(314. REAL NUMBERS AS RELATIONS. 
Summary of *314. 
In this number we take up *he definition of real numbers suggested in 
*310, namely s"G'%g instead of G'%g. The series of real numbers is now 
s»"6„ instead of %g. Everything in this number depends upon 
8)(31032. V :./a, v eG'®g. D : s'fi = s'v . =e . /t = v 
It consequence of this proposition, s \ G'%g is a correlation of the two 
sorts of real numbers, and the properties of the relational sort can be 
immediately deduced from the propositions of previous numbers. We define 
addition and multiplication of relational real numbers so as to secure that, if 
p, v are real numbers of our previous sort, the arithmetical sum of s'/u, ana 
s'v is s'(fi +a v) and their product is s'(fi xa v). This is effected by putting 
«81401. X+rF=^[(a/u,V).X = sV-F=s'I/.Jfi{sV+a»')}'S] Df 
with a similar definition for X xr Y. The zero of real numbers is now 
0„ instead of i'0g, and the negative of a real number X is X|Cnv. The 
fundamental propositions are 
«31413. Yifrve C'%g. D . sV +r s'v = .¥(ji +a v) 
«31414. \-: fi,ve G'%g. D. sV xr s'v = s'(p xa v) 
in virtue of which the arithmetical properties of relational real numbers 
follow at once from those of real numbers as segments. 
Relational real numbers are useful in applying measurement by means of 
real numbers to vector-families, since it is convenient to have real numbers 
of the same type as ratios. 
For some purposes, a somewhat different definition of real numbers as? 
relations is more convenient. Instead of deriving our relations from ©„, we 
may derive them from <*'Hg, i.e. we may consider the relations s"G'<;'Hg 
instead of the relations $"C'P>g. In virtue of «217-43, (s'Hg) I (-i'A-i'C'Hg) 
is ordinally similar to ®3; hence the requisite properties of i"C'<;'Hg follow 
at once.

SECTION B, 
VECTOR-FAMILIES. 
Summary of Section B. 
The present Section is concerned with the theory of magnitude, so far 
as this can be developed without measurement. Measurement—i.e. the 
application of ratios and real numbers to magnitudes—will be dealt with in 
Section C; for the present, we shall oonfine ourselves to those properties of 
magnitude which are presupposed in measurement. But throughout this 
Section, measurement is the goal: the hypotheses introduced and the 
propositions proved will be such as are relevant to the possibility of 
measurement. 
We conceive a magnitude as a vector, i.e. as an operation, i.e. as a 
descriptive function in the sense of *3u. Thus for example, we shall so 
define our terms, that 1 gramme would not be a magnitude, but the difference 
between t grammes and 1 gramme would be a magnitude, i.e. the relation 
" +1 gramme" would be a magnitude. On the other hand a centimetre 
and a second will both be magnitudes according to our definition, because 
distances in space and time are vectors. It will be remembered that we 
defined ratios as relations between relations; hence if ratios are to hold 
between magnitudes, magnitudes must be taken as relations. 
We demand of a vector (1) that it shall be a one-one relation, (2) that it 
shall be capable of indefinite repetition, i.e. that if the vector takes us from 
a to b, there shall always be a point c such that the vector takes us from 
b to c. If R is the vector, the point to which it takes us from a is R'a ; 
thus the above requisite is expressed by " E ! R'a . D„ . EI R'R'a," i.e. by 
" T>'R C Q'R." It will be observed that thd points which are Btarting-points 
of the vector form the class Q.'R, i.e. the class of possible arguments to K 
considered as a descriptive function, while the points which are the end- 
points of the vector form the class D'R, i.e. the class of values of R considerec 
as a descriptive function. Since D'R C Q'R, we have Q'R = C'R; thus the 
field ot the Vector consists of all points from which the vector can start. By 

340 
QUANTITY 
[PART VI 
assuming D'RCd'R, we exclude magnitudes of kinds which have a definite 
maximum, unless they are circular, like the angles at a point or the distances 
on an elliptic straight line; but, except when they are circular, such 
magnitudes are of little importance. 
According to what has just been said, if R is a vector whose field is a, we 
have 
Rel-*l.aiR**a.Y>'RCa. 
A relation which fulfils this hypothesis is called a " correspondence " of a, 
because it makes a part of a correspond with a. The class of correspondences 
of a we denote by"cr'a," which is the cardinal correlative ofcror'P," defined 
in *208. Thus we put 
cr'a = (l^l)«(T'a«D"Cl'a Df. 
We proceed next to define a vector-family of a." This we define as an 
existent sub-class of cr'a such that, if R and 8 are any two members of it, 
R | S = 81R. We define a class of relations as "Abelian " when the relative 
product of any two members of the class is commutative, i.e. we put 
Abel =k (R,SeK.OR>s.R\S=S\R) Df. 
Thus a vector-family of a is an existent Abelian sub-class of cr'o, i.e. writing 
" fm'a" for " vector-family of a," we put 
fm'o = Abel n CI ex'cr'a Df. 
The class of vector-families is then defined as everything which is a vector- 
family of some a, i.e. we put 
FM = s'V'fm Df. 
Thus a vector-family is an existent Abelian class of one-one relations 
which all have the same converse domain, and all have their domains 
contained in this common converse domain. If k is a vector-family, the 
common converse domain is i'Q."k, which is identical with s'<J."k, and will 
be called the " field " of the family. Thus we have 
I- : k e-Fi/.s. zee Abel. kC1-»1 . <1"k e 1. s'D"/tCs'<I"*:. 
A vector-family may be regarded as a kind of magnitude. In order to 
render measurement possible, we require various hypotheses as to the nature 
of the family. Measurement within a given family k is obtained by limiting 
the fields of ratios to k, i.e. by considering X [. k where X is a ratio, or Z\ k 
where Z is a relational real number of the kind defined in *314. In order 
to make measurement possible, we wish k to be such that, if X is a ratio, 
X I k shall be one-one; again, if R, S, T are members of k, and R has the 
ratio X to S, while S has the ratio Y to T, we wish R to have the ratio 
X x, Y to T, i.e. we wish to have 
Xt«|7t«G(Xxty)t«; 

SECTION B] 
VECTOR-FAMILIES 
341 
again, if R has the ratio X to T, and S has the ratio Y to T, we wish RI S 
(which represents the " sum" of R and S) to have the ratio X +aY to T, 
i.e. we wish to have 
(XtK'T)\(YtK<T)G(X+sY)tK<T. 
The above and other similar properties will be proved, with suitable 
hypotheses, in Section C; for the present, we shall proceed with the theory 
of vector-families without explicit regard to measurement. 
The first and most important hypothesis as to a family which we consider 
is the hypothesis that it is " connected," i.e. that there is at least one member 
of its field from which we can reach any member of the field by a vector 
belonging to the family or by the converse of a vector belonging to the 
family. Such a member of the field of k we shall call a " connected point" 
of k; the class of such points will be denoted by "conx'/e" ; the definition is 
-» <- 
conx'/e = s'G"k n a {s'ic'a w s'ic'a = s'Q"k) Df. 
—► 
It will be observed that s'ic'a are the points to which there is a vector from 
a, while s'ic'a are the points from which there is a vector to a. The definition 
states that these two classes together make up the whole field of the family. 
We define a connected family as one which has at least one connected point, 
i.e. we put 
FMconx =FM n *(g ! conx'/e) Df. 
The properties of connected families are many and important. Among these 
may be mentioned the following: If k is a connected family, the logical 
product of any two different members of k is null, i.e. if P, Q e k . P 4= Q, then 
Pr< Q= A, or, what comes to the same thing, if P, Qe k, and if we ever have 
P'x = Q'x, then P = Q; if P e k, all the powers of P are either members of k 
or the converses of members; if P, Q e k, then P | Q is either a member of 
k or the converse of a member. A connected family may not form a group, 
i.e. we do not necessarily have 
P.QeK.Dp.Q.PIQeK, 
but we shall show at a later stage (*354) that a group can be derived from a 
connected family k by merely adding to it the converses of those members of 
ic (if any) whose domains are equal to their converse domains. The result 
of this addition is to give us a connected family which is a group. 
Another important property of a connected family k is that I[s'Q."k is 
always a member of it. I[s'Q."k is the zero vector. In a connected family, 
every vector except I[s'Q."k is contained in diversity. For many purposes, 
the class of vectors excluding I [ s'<1"k is important. We therefore put 
ks = k - m'l Df. 

342 
QUANTITY 
[PART VI 
In the study of a vector-family k, an important derived class of relations 
is the class of all relations of the form R\S, where R,Seic. The operation 
R| S consists of an S-step forward, followed by an ii-step backward; that is 
to say, if R'S'a exists, it is obtained by moving a distance S forward from a 
to S'a, and then a distance R backward from S'a to R'S'a. The class of 
such relations as R | S, where R,Seic, we call «,; i.e. we put 
k^s'(Cuv"k)\"k Df. 
» 
The class *, will have different properties according to the nature of k. We 
may distinguish three cases : 
(1) The field of k may have a first term, i.e. there may be a member of 
s'Q."k which is not a member of s'"D"ks. This case is illustrated, e.g. by a 
family of distances from left to right on the portion of a given line not lying 
to the left of a given point. This given point will then belong to sx(I"k, 
since there are vectors which start from it, but it will not belong to s'D"kc, 
since there are no vectors which end at it except the zero vector. A 
connected point a which belongs to s'G"k but not to s'D"k^ is called the 
"initial" point, and a family which has an initial point is called an "initial' 
family. A family cannot have more than one initial point. Thus we put 
init'K = l'(conx'« - s'D'Ug) Df, 
FM mit = FM*<I'imt Df. 
(2) It may happen that, even if k is not an initial family, none of the 
converses of members of Kg are members of k. (If k is an initial family, this 
must happen.) This case is illustrated by the case of all distances towards 
the right on a straight line. It is also illustrated by the family of vectors of 
the form (+, Z) £ C'H, where Xe G'H'. In this case, as in (1), it is possible, 
by adding suitable hypotheses, to secure that s'ks shall be a series. This case 
divides into two, which are illustrated by the above two instances : it may 
happen, as in our first instance, that the domain of a vector is always equal 
to its converse domaiii, i.e. D"k = G."k ; or it may happen, as in our second 
instance, that the domain is only part of the converse domain. (The domain 
of (+, X) ^ G'H consists of all ratios greater than X.) 
(3) It may happen that Kg contains pairs of vectors which are each 
other's converses. In this case, it is obvious that s'Kg cannot be serial, since 
R,ReKg.3.R\R = I[s'(I"k .R\RG (s'Kdf, so that (s'Kgf is not contained 
in diversity (except in the trivial case k = t'A). 
In considering «„ we do not at first explicitly introduce any of the above 
possibilities, but it is necessary to bear them in mind in order to realize the

It is obvious that we shall have g Ip'C'x^ if D"k = Q"k, unless k = i'A. 
Some illustrations will serve to make clearer the nature of the hypothesis 
g!/)'(?"«,. This hypothesis states that there is at least one term a in the 
field of k such that, if R, S are any two members of k, we can either take an 
R-step forward from a, followed by an /S-step backward, or we can take an

fae NC induct. Then if R is the operation of adding fi, and Sis the operation

-B = (xoA*)C(NCinduct-i'0) and S = (x0v) £(NC induct -i'A), R\ S is the 
operation of multiplying by v and dividing by /i, with its field confined to 
inductive cardinals other than 0. If v is prime to /i, this relation has only 
multiples of /t in its converse domain and only multiples of v in its domain. 
Hence its field consists of multiples of fi together with multiples of v. Thus 
no member of k, except I[s'G"k, i.e. (x01)£ (NC induct - t'O), has the 
whole of s'Q."k for its field, and there is no number which belongs to the

field of every member of /et. The above family may be usefully borne in 
mind in considering /et, since it affords good illustrations of most of the 
general theorems concerning /e,. 
If* is any family except t'A, any finite number of members of /e, have an 
existent relative product, and their converse domains have an existent 
logical product. If /e is a connected family, any two members L, M of *-, 
whose logical product exists, i.e. for which (33/). L'y = M'y, are identical, and 
if x,y are any two members of s'CL"k, there is just one member of «, such 
that «= L'y. If MeK, and P is a power of M, there is some member L of 
«, such that P C L. But P is not in general itself a member of «,. For the 
application of ratio, the member of Kt which contains P is important. We 
call it the "representative" of P. The general definition of a representative is 
rep/P = *'(«, « G'P) Df. 
<— 
In a connected family, k, n C'P cannot have more than one member; hence 
if there is any member of /et which contains P, that member is rep/P, and if 
there is no member of «, which contains P, rep/P = A. 
If P I Q is any member of «, (where P,Qe /e), we shall have 
rep«'(P I QY = P>\Q>\ 
and if L,M e kl, we shall have 
rep,<(Z- I My = rep, '(£" | if") = rep/{(rep,'Z>) | (rep/M")}. 
These two formulae are the most useful in determining representatives. 
In order to apply the above theory to the measurement of vectors, it is 
necessary to distinguish between open and cyclic families. An open family 
is one in which, if M e /e< - Rl'I, Mpo G J, i.e. one in which no number of 
repetitions of a non-zero member of /el will bring us back to our starting- 
point. If this condition fails, as in the case of angles, or distances on the 
elliptic straight line, the problem of measurement is more complicated, since, 
if 8 is a measure of an angle, so is 2vrr + 6 for any integral v. The case of 
cyclic families will be considered in Section D; for the present, we proceed 
to consider open families, and we shall still be concerned almost exclusively 
with open families in Section C. It should be observed that in cyclic 
families, as we shall define them, members of /eg return into themselves, 
whereas in open families, not merely no member of /eg, but no member of 
k, — R1'7, returns into itself. In most of the families that naturally occur, 
it happens either that no member of «, — Rl'J returns into itself, or that 
there are members of /eg which do so. But there is no logical necessity in 
this, as the following instance shows: Consider the family consisting of 
positive and negative integral multipliers other than — 1, with their fields 
confined to positive and negative integers other than — 1. Then 1 is a 

SECTION B] 
VECTOR-FAMILIES 
345 
connected point of this family, in fact the initial point. Multiplication by 
— 1 is a member of *,, since it can be obtained by multiplying by any integer 
fi and then dividing by — fi. Also the square of multiplication by — 1 is 
contained in identity, and is the zero vector of our family. Hence there is a 
member of «, — Rl'J whose square is contained in identity, although no power 
of any member of ks is contained in identity. 
In order to avoid brackets, we put 
Kti = («Oa Df> 
i.e. kiS = kl - Rl'I. 
Then the definition of open families is 
FM ap = FM r, k (a'Potf'Ka C Rl'J) Df. 
Hence h :. k e FM ap. = : k e FM: M e kiS . DM. Mvo C J. 
It will be observed that if k is an open family, /e, is contained in Rel num id 
(cf. *300), and «,a C Rel num. Hence if M e k#, M" = Mv (cf. *121), and the 
propositions on intervals in *121 become available. Also if MeiclS, and 
aes'd"K, we have 
^ —► ^ —► 
MI M^'a e Prog . M^ £ M^'a e a>. 
The chief use of these facts is to show that the existence of open families 
implies the axiom of infinity and the existence of bt0. Hence as applied to 
open families, the theory of ratio undergoes the very great simplification 
which results from the axiom of infinity.

These propositions, together with

We next proceed to consider serial families, which are those in which 
s'/eg is an existent serial relation. For this purpose we require the definition 
of " FM connex" already given, and also the definition of "transitive" 
families. We define a as a " transitive point" of k if 
—* —» 
(s'KSy's(Kg'a C s'tcg'a, 
i.e. if any point which can be reached from a in two non-null steps can also 
he reached in one non-null step. We define a family as transitive when it 
has at least one transitive point. If k e FMconx, the hypothesis that k is 
transitive is equivalent to the hypothesis that *g forms a group, and implies 
that k forms a group. We define a serial family as one which is transitive 
and has connexity, i.e. we put 
FM sr = FM trs n FM connex Df. 
Then if k e FM sr, s'/eg is a serial relation, so that the points of the field of k 
are arranged in a series by means of relations of distance. 
When a family is serial, the vectors also can be arranged in a series, by 
means of a relation which may be regarded as that of greater and less. After 
a short number on initial families (explained above), we proceed to the 
consideration of greater and less (as it may be called) among vectors. We 
may call a point y " earlier " than a point z when there is a non-null vector 
which goes from y to z, i.e. when z (s'ks) y. If M, N e tct, we then say that N 
is "less" than M if the iV-step from some point x takes us to an earlier 
point than the i/-step. Writing VK for " greater than " among members of 
*,, our definition is 
VK = MN [M, N e «,: (a«). (M'x) (*'«8) (N'x)} Df. 
For the same relation confined to members of k, we use the notation UK; 
thus 
U^V.t* Df. 
If k e FM conx, we have 
UK = PQ {P, Q e k : (gT). Te *8 - P = T\ Q]; 
this is generally the most serviceable formula for UK. 
If k is a serial family, UK and VK are series ; and if k is an initial family, 
UK is similar to s'/eg. 
The last number in this Section is concerned with the axiom ot 
Archimedes and with the existence of sub-multiples of vectors. The axiom 
of Archimedes will be expressed by saying that if a is any member of the 

SECTION B] 
VECTOR-FAMILIES 
347 
field of k, and R is any vector, then Bf'a, for a sufficiently great finite v, will 
be later than any assigned member of the field of k. In other words, putting 
P = Cnv's'*g, we wish to have 
x e C'P. Dx. (g!/). v e NC ind -1<0 . xP (R"a), 
or, what comes to the same thing, 
P"R#'a = C'P. 
This will hold if k is a serial family and P is semi-Dedekindian (cf. *214). 
If, further, P is compact (i.e. P2 = P), then all finite sub-multiples of a given 
vector exist, i.e. 
S e k . v e NC ind - i'O . D . (gl) . Z e k . & = Z/. 
It will be observed that, according to our definition of ratio, if S = L" and 
#4= A, L has to S the ratio l/i/, so that L is the i/th sub-multiple of & 
Instead of treating vector-families by the method we have adopted, we 
might have started from a double descriptive function, which we may denote 
hy x+y, and concerning which we should make various hypotheses. By the 
general notation of *38, we obtain various relations of the form +-y or * + . 
These relations may replace the k employed in our method. For convenience 
of notation, we may put 
+'y= + y Df, 
<— 
+'x = x+ Df. 
—» 
Then if + has suitable properties, and -y is a suitable class, +"y will be a 
vector family. 
Let us assume that x + y exists when, and only when, ic and y both 
belong to the class 7, and that when x and y both belong to the class y,x + y 
also belongs to this class. Then it x + y exists, so does ic + y +y\ hence 
D'4 y C <J'+ y. Further, by our assumptions, if x,yey, x+y exists, and 
therefore xeQ.-+y. Hence yey.D.Q.'+y=y. Hence if 7 exists, 
a"+*"y e 1. s'D"+"7 c s(a"+"y. 
If we now assume y + x= z + x. 3x,y.z -y~z> 
then +"7 C 1 —> 1. Hence we now have 
-+ 
+"7 6 CI ex'Cr'7. 
In order to obtain the Abelian property, we require 
(x + y) + z = (x + z)+y, 
which holds if + obeys the permutative and associative laws. Thus in this 
case, 
—» 
+ "7 6 fm'7. 

348 QUANTITY [PART VI 
~* 
In order that +"7 may be a connected family, we reauire 
(ga) i.zey.3t: (ay) :a = « + y.v.* = a + y. 
A sufficient, though not a necessary, condition for this is that there should be 
a zero, i.e. 
(go): z ey .¾. z -a + z. 
In this case, + a is the zero vector, and if a is not the sum *f two terms other 
than itself, a is the initial point of the family. 
-> 
The condition that if x,y are members of 7 so is x + y secures that +"7 
is a group. Families which are groups we denote by " FM grp." 
Thus collecting what has been said, we find that 
-+ 
+"7e-JWconx8rP 
if + fulfils the following conditions: 
(1) x + y exists when, and only when, x, y e 7; 
(2) x,yey.^x,y.<c+yey; 
(3) x + y = x + z.DXiy,t.y=:z; 
(4) x+y = y + x; 
(5) (x + y) + z = x + (y+z); 
(6) (Qa):zey.D,i.z = a+z. 
From (3) and (4) it follows that the a of (6) is unique, i.e. there cannot be 
more than one zero. 
In order to insure that our family shall have connexity, we require 
further 
(7) x, y e 7 . DXilf: (qz) :zey:x + z = y.v.y + z = x; 
(8) in order that our family may be an initial family we require that 
x + y shall only be zero when x and y are zero. 
With this further condition, our family becomes serial. 
The above is only a sketch of one of the simplest ways of generating 
families by means of double descriptive functions. Other *ays are possible, 
and by greater complication greater generality can be obtained. 
There are some advantages in the above manner of treatment. First, it 
is possible to take our magnitudes as being the x and y which appear in 
" x+y" instead of having to take them as the vectors +yor«+. Secondly, 
our vector-family derives unity from the fact of being generated by the 
single operation +. Thirdly, the method is more in agreement with current 
conceptions of quantity than the method we have adopted. The choice 

SECTION B] 
VECTOB FAMILIES 
349 
between the two methods is a matter of taste; but it would seem that the 
method we have adopted is capable of somewhat greater generality than the 
other, and that it requires less new technical apparatus than the other. We 
have not elsewhere had occasioa to treat of double descriptive functions 
which only exist when their arguments belong to assigned classes, though 
it is to be observed that our definitions of various kinds of addition and 
multiplication might quite easily have been so framed as to give this result. 
For instance, we might have put 
/*+0i> = (7«r) {(go, /3). /j. = N0c'a. „ = N0c'/3 . «r = Nc'(a + /3)} Df. 
In that case, E!(/i+0i;) would have implied /j., i/eN0C, whereas with our 
definition it is only g ! (jj, +„ v) that implies /*, v e N0C. The general treatment 
of double functions which only exist in certain cases would require a 
considerable logical apparatus not required elsewhere in our work, and this 
is, for us, a reason against adopting the method of treating vector-families 
which derives them, as in the above sketch, from a single function x + y. 

*330. ELEMENTARY PEOPEETIES OF VECTOR-FAMILIES. 
Summary of #330 
In this number, we begin by defining tne class of " correspondences " of 
a. A " correspondence" of a is a one-one relation R which makes every 
member of a correspond to an a, i.e. which is such that, if x e a, R'x always 
exists and is a member of a. Thus, for example, if ft is an inductive number, 
+„/*, with its field limited to inductive numbers, is a correspondence of the 
class of inductive numbers, provided the axiom of infinity holds. (Otherwise, 
(+0 /j.) I NC induct is not one-one.) The definition of correspondences of 
a is 
*33001. cr'a=(l^l)rt(I'anD''Cl'a Df 
I.e. a correspondence of a is a one-one relation whose converse domain is 
a and whose domain is contained in a. The definition should be compared 
with the definition of " cror'P " in *208. 
It will be seen that if Rebr'a and xe&, R'x exists and is an a, and 
therefore R'R'x exists and is an a, and so on. Hence all the powers of 
R exist (*330-23). Similarly if R, S, T, ... are any finite number of  
correspondences of a, R\S\T\... exists. This is proved for two and three factors 
in *330-21-22. 
We define a " vector-family of a" as an existent Abelian class of 
correspondences of a, where an Abelian class of relations is defined as one 
such that the relative product of any two of its members is commutative. 
Thus we put 
*33002. Abel = Z(R,SeK .DBtS. R\S= S\R) Df 
*33003. fm'a = Abel n Cl ex'cr'a Df 
*33004. PJ/ = s'D'fm Df 
It will be remembered that Potid'P and (for certain kinds of. relations) 
finid'P are Abelian classes of relations (*91'34 and *121'352). If Pel —»1, 
Potid'P will be a vector-family of C'P, and if further PV0(LJ, finid'P will be 
the same vector-family. 
One other definition belongs to this number, namely 
*33005. «,«.8'(Cnv"«)|"« Df 
This definition has been sufficiently discussed in the summary of the 
present Section.

properties are mainly such as assert the existence of relative products, and 
of logical products of converse domains, or such as assert commutativeness of 
the relative product under certain circumstances. The earlier propositions 
deal with members of k, the later propositions mainly with members of «,.

it is necessary to have E ! X*>. E ! M", and by *301'16 this inay fail if either 
p or a is null in the type of X and M. The existence of a family does not 
imply the axiom of infinity, since the family may be cyclic.

*331. CONNECTED FAMILIES. 
Summary of *331. 
A "connected point" of a family k is a point of the field of k from which 
every member of the field can be reached by a member of k or the converse 
of a member. That is, if a is a connected point, we are to have 
x e s'Q"k . 3^ . (gi£) . Rex .x(Rv R) a 
as well as a e s'Q."k. This amounts to saying that every member of s'G."k 
is of the form R'a or R'a, where R e k. The definition is 
#331-01. conx'/e = s'<I"k n a(s'K'a w s'k'o, = s'(I"/c) Df 
Here we include the factor s'Q."k in the definition, in order to exclude 
the case when k = I'A. If s'Wk were not included, we should have 
eonx'i'A = V, whereas with'the above definition conx'i'A = A. 
In the case of any other family, the factor s'Q"* makes no difference, 
since if s'G"k exists, 
—» <— 
s'ic'a w s'ic'a = s'Q"k . D . a e C's'k, 
and if k is a family, C's'k = s'G"k. But in the case of I'A, the factor 
s'Q"k insures that no connected point exists, thus securing, conversely, that 
a family which has a connected point is not I'A. This is convenient, since 
the case of I'A, which is trivial, would often otherwise have to be explicitly 
excluded. 
The definition would be more analogous to the definition of a connected 
relation in *202 if we put 
—» <— 
oonx'/c = s'<I"k n a (s'KJa w s(Kd'a w I'a = s'Wk) Df. 
But this definition fails to give us the information that there is a member 
of k which relates a to itself, whereas our definition does give this  
information, and hence leads to the proof that I f s'Q."k e k, i.e. that there is a zero 
vector. 
We say that a family " is connected " when it has at lp.ast one connected 
point, i.e. we put 
*331-02. FM conx = FM n k (a ! conx'/c) Df 

SECTION B] 
CONNECTED FAMILIES 
361 
When all points of the field are connected points, the family " has con- 
nexity" (cf. *334'27), provided *=|=i'A. For the present, we only assume 
tbat at least one of the points of the field is a connected point. To 
take an illustration; the family whose members are of the form 
(x0/*)£ (NC induct—I'O), where p. e NC induct — l'0, has only one con- 
aected point, namely 1. If we had taken positive and negative integers, 
both a? multipliers and as constituting the field, we should have had two 
connected pointo, namely 1 and — 1. 
Almost all our future propositions on vector-families will be confined to 
connected families. In the present number, we prove first that in a connected 
family k, the vector which relates a connected point to itself also relates any 
other member of the field to itself (*331'2), whence it follows that I f s'Q."k 
is a member of k (*331'22), and that every other member of k is wholly 
contained in diversity (*331*23), and that «wCnv"*C«, (*331-24). We 
next prove that the product of two members of k is a member of k or of 
Cbv"k (*331'33). We then proceed to consider «„ and prove at once the 
two fundamental properties of /e, in a connected family, namely (1) that 
between any two members of s'Q"k there is a relation which is a member 
of kc (*331'4), and (2) that two members of /e, whose logical product exists 
are identical (*331*42), From these two propositions it follows that there is 
just one member of /e, which relates any two members of s'Q"* (#331*43). 
Finally we prove that any power of a member of k is a member of k w Cnv"/e 
(*33r54), and that any power of a member of *, is contained in some member 
of ^(#331-56). 
Stated symbolically, the above propositions are as follows:

*332. ON THE REPRESENTATIVE OF A RELATION IN A FAMILY. 
Summary of *332. 
We saw at the end of the last number (*331"56) that any power of a 
member of *\ is contained in a member of Kt. When a relation is contained 
in a member of k„ we call this member the "representative" of the relation 
in the family. For purposes connected with the application of ratio, the 
"representative" is an important function of a relation, especially when the 
relation concerned is a power of a member of *\. By the definition of ratio 
(*30301), we shall have L(p/o) M if g ! L" r> M" and p Prm a. Now if L" 
and M<> each have a representative, then they must have the same representative 
if g ! Lq fs Mp (by *331'42). Hence we are enabled to substitute an equality 
for g ! If n M'? in dealing with ratios of members of «,. The elementary 
properties of representatives are dealt with in the present number. 
We denote the representative of P in the family k by " rep/P." In order 
to insure E! rep/P under all circumstances, we do not define rep/P as the 
only member of «, which contains P, but as the logical sum of the class of 
members of /e, which contain P, i.e. we put 
*33201. rep/P = s<(k< « G'P) Df 
<— 
In a connected family, if P is not null, k, n G'P cannot have more than 
one member (*332'21), and therefore the representative of P, if it is not null, 
must be a member of *\ (*332'22). If P is a member of «,, it is its own 
representative (*332'241). 
We prove in this number that, if P, Q, R,... have existent representatives, 
the representative of their relative product (unless this product is null) is 
the representative of the relative product of their representatives (*332'37). 
Among other important propositions in this number are the following : 
*332'32. r : k e FM conx . L, M e k, . D . rep/(X | M) = repK'(M\ L) 
*332-51. h : Ke FM conx. P,Q e k. D . rep/(P | Q)= Q\P 
*33253. h : k e FM conx . P, Q e k . p e NC induct. D . rep/(P | Qy = P» \ Q" 
*332'61. h:«6 FM conx . L e k, . D . rep/'Potid'Z C /e,

*333. OPEN FAMILIES. 
Summary of *333. 
An " open " family is denned as one such that, if L is any member of /e, 
which is not contained in identity, then every power of L is contained in 
diversity, i.e. L^ G J. We shall often have occasion, both in this number 
and later, to consider the class /e, — Rl'J, and in later numbers we shall often 
have occasion to consider the class k — Rl'I. We therefore put 
«88801. Kd=K-m'I Df 
«888011. icld = Ut)d Df 
Thus kiS consists of all members of k, which are not contained in identity, 
i.e. (if k is a connected family) all members of /c, except I \ s'Q."k. The 
definition of an "open" family is 
«33302. FM ap = FM n> k (s'Pot"*:tg C Rl'J} Df 
From the point of view of the application of ratio, the hypothesis that 
a family is open is very important. To begin with, it insures (#333-18) 
that /e.g consists of "numerical" relations (cf. *300), so that if Leic^, we 
have Pot'Z = fin'Z (*333-15), and in virtue of «300-491, the existence of 
open families implies the axiom of infinity (*333'19). 
Again, in an open connected family, if L, M are two different members 
of *,, all the powers of L | M are contained in diversity, and therefore the 
representatives of these powers are members of Ktg; that is, we have 
*333'22. h : k e FM ap conx . L, M e «,. L + M. D . reP/["Pot'(£ | M) C Kid 
It follows from this proposition that, with the above hypothesis, if <r lS 
any inductive cardinal other than 0, L" | M" is not contained in identity, and 
therefore L" =J= M" and rep/Z> =$= rep/M". Hence by transposition we obtain 
the two propositions : 
«333-41. V :. k e FM ap conx . L, M e k, . o- e NC ind -1'0 . D : 
repK'Lv = rep/if" . = .L = M 

SECTION B] OPEN FAMILIES 377 
*33342. h :. Hp *33341 .3:L'=M'. = .L = M 
Hence we obtain 
*333 43. h :. Hp *33341 .:>:£! L° * M° . = . L = M 
This proposition shows that in an open connected family, no two 
members of /e, have the ratio 1/1 unless they are identical. Again it 
follows from *333'41 that if I/X°T and MaXcT have the same representative, 
then Z> and M" have the same representative, and vice versa, i.e. 
«33344. V :. k e FMap conx . L, Me k, . p, a-, t e NC ind - t'O . D : 
repK'ZpXoT = repK'M<rX'T. = . rep/Is = rep^M" 
Hence we obtain two propositions which are vital for the application of 
ratio, namely : 
*333'47. h :. k e FM ap conx . L, M e /c,. p, a e NC ind - t'O . D : 
rep,c'2> = rep^M" . = . g I If h M' 
«33348. h :. k e FM ap conx . L, M e /c,. p, a, t e NC ind - t'O . D : 
3 ! Zp r> ilf" . = . 3 ! Z>X«T /S M'*'T 
On comparing this last proposition with the definition of ratio (*303'01), 
it will be seen that, whether p is prime to a- or not, L has to M the ratio a-jp 
when, and only when, g ! L' f\ M", i.e. (by *333'47) when, and only when, 
rep/i/ = rep^'itf". 
From *333'47 it follows also that, if M e *l5, i/p and M" will not have the 
same representative unless p = a- (*33351), i.e. 
*333'51. h :. k e FM&p conx . Me kiS .p,<re NC ind. D : 
repK'3fp = rep/itf". = . p = <r 
From this it follows that no member of k^ has any other ratio to itself 
than 1/1. Again, by *333-47-48'51, we have 
*333 53. h : k eFMap conx . L, M e kiS . g ! L" A M". g ! Is n A/> . D . 
fi,x0a-~ v xoP 
Hence if L and Jlf have the two ratios pjcr, fi/v, we have p/a- = /i/i>; that 
is, no two members of «,g have more than one ratio. 
The applications of ratio indicated in this summary will not be made till 
the following Section; they are here mentioned in order to show the utility 
of the propositions of the present number.

*334. SERIAL FAMILIES. 
Summary of *334. 
The purpose of the present number is to consider what properties of 
a family k will insure that s'Kg is serial, or has one or more of the properties 
characteristic of serial relations. Suppose, for example, that k consists of  
distances on a line. Then Kg consists of those distances which are members of* 
and are not zero. Any selection of distances on the line may constitute k; thus 
e.g. k may consist of all distances which are integral multiples of a given distance, 
or of all which are rational multiples of a given distance., or of all distances 
from left to right, or of all distances on the line in either direction. It is 
plain to begin with that if s'/eg is to be serial, /c must not contain equal 
distances in opposite directions, since if it does, (s'/cg)2 will not be contained 
in diversity, i.e. s'Kg will not be asymmetrical We call a family k  
asymmetrical when no member of Kg has a converse which is also a member of 
Kg. The definition is 
*33405. FMasym **FMr\2(Kr\ Cnv"* C R\'I) Df 
It will be observed that s'KgQJ in any connected family, by *331'23. If 
KeFMasym, we have also (s'KgyCJ. 
In order to secure that s'Kg shall be transitive, we require that the field of 
* should contain at least one "transitive point," where a "transitive point" 
means a point a such that any point which can be reached from a by two 
successive non-zero steps can also be reached by one non-zero step, i.e. such 
that 
—» -» 
(s'KsY's'Kg'aCs'Kg'a. 
The definition of transitive points is 
*33401. trs'ic = s'(1"k n a {(s«K3)"s'«3«a C s'Kd'a} Df 
Thus if a is a transitive point, and R,SeK^, there is always a member of 
Kg, say T, such that R'8'a=T'a. It will be seen that if k is a connected 
family, the existence of a transitive point implies that the family is  
asymmetrical. Again, if there is a transitive point in a connected family, then 
R,8e Kg.D . R\8e Kg, by *331"32; hence Kg is a group. The converse also 

384 QUANTITY [PART VI 
holds, i.e. if /eg is a group, any member s'Q."k is a transitive point (*334-ll). 
Hence if there is any transitive point, every point of s'Q."k is a transitive 
point. 
The definition of a transitive family is 
*33402. FM trs = FM n £ (a ! trs'«) Df 
By what has just been said, a connected transitive family is one in which /eg 
is a group, i.e. 
*33413. \-uice FMconx . D : /c e FMtrs. = . s'ks \"icd C «.3 
A connected family is transitive when, and only when, s'ks is a transitive 
relation, i.e. 
*33414. h :. k e FM conx . D : k e FM trs . = . s'ks e trans 
In order to secure that s'ks shall be a connected relation, it is not enough 
that k should be an FM conx, i.e. that s'Q."k should have at least one  
connected point. We require that every point of s'Q."k should be a connected 
point. This will be secured if there is a connected point which belongs to 
the field of every member of «„ i.e. if 
3 Iconx'/e r\p'C"Kt. 
For suppose aeconx'/e r\p'C"Kt. Then if Le*„ either L'a or L'a exists, and 
is of the form R'a or R'a, where Rex. Hence, by «331*32, L is identical 
with R or with R ; hence k, = k w Cnv"*. Hence by *331*4, s'ks e connex. 
Conversely, if k e FM conx and s'/cg e connex, it follows from *33132 that 
«,=/cuCnv"«; hencep'G"k1=s'(I"k, and therefore we have alconx'/enp'O"*,. 
Hence putting 
*334*03. FM connex = FM n £ (3 ! conx'/c np'C"*:,) Df 
where "FJlf connex " means "families having connexity," we have 
*33426. h :. k e FM conx . D : /c e fi/ connex . = . s'k3 e connex . 
= . «, == « u Cnv"« . = . C"«, = d"/c 
and 
*33427. h. FJf connex = i<Wr»/c(s'(I"*: = conx'* ./c + i'A) 
/.e. a family having connexity is one whose field consists wholly of connected 
points and is not null. 
We thus secure CD s'/cg G J by the hypothesis k e FM conx, (2) s'/Cg e trans 
by the hypothesis veFMconx n FM trs, (3) s'/c^ e connex by the hypothesis 
/e e J^A/ connex (which implies k e FM conx). Hence we secure s'x^eSer by 
the hypothesis k e FM trs n Mf connex. Wlien this hypothesis is fulfilled, 
we call /c a "serial " family ; thus we put 

SECTION B] 
SERIAL FAMILIES 
385 
#33404. FM sr = FM ti-s n i<W connex Df 
and we have 
#3343. V : k e FM sr . Z> . *««8 e Ser 
#334 31. hz./eeFilf./^s'a'Ve/c.Dj/ceFilf sr . = . s'*g eSer-i'A 
An important special case, which is briefly considered in this number is 
the case when the domains of members of k are the same as their converse 
domains, i.e. when 
T>"K = a"K. 
This case is illustrated, e.g. by the family whose members are all relations of 
the form (+gX)[rC'Hg, where XeC'H. It is also illustrated by cyclic 
families, which are considered in the next Section but one. When D"k = Q."k, 
if k is a family, so is k w Cnv"* (#334-4), and if k is a connected family, so is 
k w Onv"*: (#334-41). In the case of the above family, whose members are 
(+gX)l C'Hg where XeC'H', ituCnv"* will consist of all relations 
(+gX)l. C'Hg where X eC'Hg, i.e. it will consist of all additions of positive 
or negative ratios to positive or negative ratios. 
A connected family in which D"k = Q."k is a family having con- 
nexity, i.e. 
#33442. h : k e FMconx. D"k = Q."k . D. k e FM connex 
The definitions and propositions of this number are much used  
throughout the remainder of Part VI.

#335. INITIAL FAMILIES. 
Summary of *335. 
A family of vectors may or may not have a point in its field which is a 
starting-point but not an end-point of non-zero vectors. For example, the 
family of which a member is (+, X) t C'H', where X e C'H', has such a point 
in its field, namely 00; but the family of which a member is (+eX)l C'H, 
where X e C'H', has no such point in its field, and no more has the family of 
which a member is (+g X) I C'Hg, where X e C'H'. If such a point exists, it 
is a member of s'Q."k but not of s'D"/^. Such a point, if it is also a  
connected point, must be unique, i.e. we have 
#33512. 1-: k eFM. Z> . conx'* -s'D"«8eOu] 
When conx'/e — s'D"ks exists, we call its only member "the initial point 
of k," putting 
#336-01. init'*: = ^'(conx'/e - s'~D"icd) Df 
If the initial point of k exists, we call k an " initial" family; thus we put 
*335 02. FM init = FM n d'init Df 
An initial family is asymmetrical (#33516) and transitive ($335-18), and 
forms a group (#335-17); and if its initial point is a member of p'C"ict, it is a 
serial family (*335-3). 
#336-01. init'*='i'(conx'*:-s'D"*:8) Df 
#336-02. FM init = FM n d'init Df 
—> <— 
#33611. h : k eFM. a e conx'/e - s'T>"ks . D . s'd"* = s'K'a. I'a = s'K'a

*335-3. \-:KeFM.inittKeptC"Kl.O.stKdeSer [*33521-22] 

*336. THE SERIES OE VECTORS. 
Summary of *33tj. 
In this number we consider a relation between members of k or of /c, 
which, with suitable limitations as to the nature of the family, may he 
identified with the relation of greater and less. If there is a member of k 
which takes us from a point z to a point y, i.e. if y(s'Kg)z, we say that z is an 
earlier point than y; thus we regard s'k% as the relation of later to earlier. 
If now M and N are two members of «„ and if, for some x, M'x is later than 
N'x, we shall say that M is "greater" than N with respect to k. This 
relation we denote by VK, where " V" is intended to suggest that the relation 
holds between vectors. The definition is: 
«336-01. 7« = ^{3/,jRTe«.:(afl!).(Jf'fl!)(«««8)(jRr«fl!)} Df 
For the same relation when confined to members of k, we use the notation 
UK; thus we put 
•336011. Uk = VkIk Df 
In dealing with VK and UK it is desirable to be able to express M'x as a 
function of M. We wish to consider (say) a fixed origin a, and the various 
points R'a, S'a, T'a, ... to which the various vectors which are members of k 
carry us from a. For this purpose we put 
R<a=.Aa'R, 
where " A " stands for " argument," and " Aa'R " may be read " the vaiue, 
for the argument a, of R." The definition is 
Aa=&R(xRa) Df, 
whence we obtain 
«336101. V : E ! R'a. D . R'a = Aa'R 
Then the points R'a,S'a, T'a,..., where R,S,T, ... are the various members 
of k, form the class Aa"ic, which is thus the same class as s'/c'a. The relation 
-An T /c correlates the point R'a with the vector R. The vector R is analogous 
to the coordinate of R'a when a is the origin ; thus Aa [ k is analogous to 
the relation of a point to its coordinate. A relation which is more exactly 
that of a point to its coordinate will be explained in Section C, where, in 
26 

394 
QUANTITY 
[PART VI 
addition to the above correlator Aa f k, we shall also correlate a vector with 
its numerical measure in terms of an assigned unit. 
If k is a connected family, and a is any point of its field, Aa [ /e, is a one- 
one relation (*336-2). If k is an initial family, and a is its initial point, 
Aa[k is a correlator of s'(I"k and k (*336-21), so that in an initial family 
the class of vectors is similar to the field (*336'22). If k is a connected 
family, and a is any point of the field, and X is those members L of /e, for 
which L'a exists, then Aa [ X correlates the field with X, so that X is similar 
to the field (*336"24). 
By the definition of Aa, if Me /c, and M'a exists, we have 
M'a = Aa'M=Aatic>'M. 
Hence by the definition of VK, 
\-:MVKN. = . (ga). (Aa [Ki'M)(s<Kd)(Aa [«.'#). 
= .(aa).Jf(*.1 AJi'Kd)N, by »150-41. 
Similarly h : PUKQ . = . (go) . P («1 AJs'ks) Q. 
Now in a connected family, if a and b are any two members of the field, and 
P.Qbk, 
(P'u) (i'Kd) (Q'a). = . (P'b) (a'«8) (Q'b) (*336'38); 
hence k 1 Ajs'tcQ = k 1 AJs'kq, 
and hence UK = k 1 AJs'ks (*336-43). 
Since k 1 40 is one-one (by *336'2), the above gives an ordinal correlation of 
UK with (s'K'0) ^ Aa"ic («336-461), i.e. UK is ordinally similar to s'/e9 with its 
field confined to those points which can be reached from a by vectors which 
are members of k. If k is an initial family, it follows that UK is similar to 
i'/Cg (*336'44) ; if not, UK is in general only similar to a segment of s'ks (in 
the sense of *213). 
It should be observed that /c, 1 Aa'x is the member of /e, which takes us 
from a to x, and /c'j Aa'x (if it exists) is the member of k which takes us from 
a to as. Thus k] Aa's'ics is the series of vectors which take us from a to all 
the various points which can be reached from a by members of k, the order 
of the series being that of the points to which the various vectors take us 
from a. 
If k is a connected family, UK is the relation which holds between two 
members of k when one of them is the relative product of the other and a 
third (other than the zero vector), i.e. 
*336-4l. r : Ke FM conx .3 .UK = PQ{P,Qe k : (aT). T e Kh. P =T\Q\ 

SECTION B] THE SERIES OF VECTORS 395 
This is lor many purposes the most convenient formula for UK. If, in 
addition, we have D"/e = Q."k, a similar formula holds for VK, i.e. 
*336 54. r : K eFMconx . B"k = <I"k .D . 
VK = MN \M,NeK<: (rT) .T e,cb.M =T\N\ 
If k 6 FM conx, VK is contained in diversity (*336'6); if /c is also transitive, 
VK is transitive (336-61); and if k has connexity, so has VK (*336-62). Hence 
if k is a serial family, VK and UK are serial (#33663-64). 
In addition to the above-mentioned propositions, the iollowing  
propositions in this number are important : 
#336411. h :. k e FM conx .s'k \"k C /c . D : PUKQ . R e k .3 . (P | R) UK(Q | R) 
#336511. h :. k e FMsr . „e NC ind - i<0. D : RUKS . = . E-'^S-' 
#33653. h :. *e P3f conx . M, Ne/c,. D: MVKN. = . NVJd 
The present number is important, since VK and [7* are the general 
relations from which greater and less among magnitudes are derived, and 
the subject of magnitude is therefore intimately dependent upon them.

*33663. \-: KeFMsr . D.F,eSer [#336661-62] 
*336 64. YiKeFMm.O.U^eSer [*33663] 

*337. MULTIPLES AND SUB-MULTIPLES OF VECTORS. 
Summary of *337. 
In this number, we are concerned with the axiom of Archimedes and the 
axiom of divisibility. If * is a family of vectors, k obeys the axiom of 
Archimedes if, given any two points x, a in the field of k, and any vector 
R which is a member of k, there is some power R" of R such that R"'a is 
later than x. That is, k obeys the axiom of Archimedes if, starting from 
any given point in the field, a sufficient finite number of repetitions of any 
given vector will take us beyond any other assigned point. A sufficient 
hypothesis for this is that k should be serial and Cnv's'/eg should be semi- 
Dedekindian (cf. *214), i.e. we have 
#337*13. \-:. tc e FM sr. P = s'tc^ . P e semi Ded . R e *g. a e G'P. D : 
xeC'P.-}. (a*). v e NC ind - t'O . xP (R"a) 
The hypothesis P — s'ks, which appears in the above proposition, is often 
notationally convenient. It will be observed that s'/eg gives tis the series 
in the opposite order to that in which it is usually wanted; hence the  
introduction cf the above relation P tends to avoid confusions. 
A family k is said to obey the axiom of divisibility when, given any 
member R of k, and any jnductive cardinal v other than 0, there is a 
member L of k such that L" = R. When this axiom holds, every vector 
can be divided into any assigned finite number of equal parts. We shall in 
the next Section (*351) define a family for which this holds as a "sub-multi- 
pliable family," denoted by " FM subm." For the present we are concerned 
to find a hypothesis as to s'/eg from which this property can be deduced. 
The hypothesis in question is that Cnv's'/eg is serial, compact, and semi- 
Dedekindian; i.e. we have 
*337"27. h :. k e FM sr . Cnv's'/eg e comp n semi Ded . D : 
S e k . v e NC ind - t'O . D . (gX) .Leic.S^L" 
The proof proceeds by taking two points a, x in the field of k, of which a is 
earlier than x, and considering the class 
\ = KdnR{(R*'a)Px\, 

404 
QUANTITY 
[PART VI 
i.e. the class of vectors such that v repetitions of them, starting from a, do 
not take us as far as m. It is easy to show that, when P is compact, this 
class has no maximum (#33723), and therefore, when P is also semi-Dede- 
kindian, has a limit, whose vth power is the vector which takes us from a to 
x (#337-26). Hence our result follows. 
•8871. h : keFM.P = 8'icd. Me Kd .ae G'P . D . R#'a CP"R*'a 
Dem. 
V . #9016 . #41-141 . D V : Hp. xR*a .y=R'x.3.ye R#'a . xPy. 
[*37l] D . a; e P"R\'a: D V . Prop 
^ —► —► 
#33711. h : k eFMconnexasym .P= s'icd.Re Kd.aeG'P.D.aeqP'R#'a = A 
Dem. 
h . #20615 . D h: Hp .D. aeqP'R*'a = p*P"R\'a - P"p'P~"R*'a (1) 
h .#330-542 .#4061. D h : Hp.xep'P"R#'a .3.xe V'R. 
[Hp] D. (gc).x = R'c. cPx (2) 
h. #90-172. Dh:ceiVa-3-£'ce *Va (3) 
—» 
I-. (3). Transp . #200-5. #334-5 . D h : Hp (2). x = iJ'c . D ~c ~ e iV<z (4) 
1-. #371. D h : ceP"R*'d. Z>. (a6). 6 e£*'a. cPb (5) 
I-. (5).#208-2 . D h : Hp . ceP"R*'a .x**R'c.3. ($b). beR#'a. xP(R'b).

SECTION C. 
MEASUREMENT. 
Summary of Section G. 
In this Section, the "pure" theory of ratios and real numbers developed 
in Section A is applied to vector-families. A vector-family, if it has suitable 
properties, may be regarded as a kind of magnitude. In order to derive from 
the " pure" theory of ratio a theory of measurement having the properties 
which we should expect, it is necessary to confine ourselves to some one 
vector-family; that is, instead of considering the general relation X, where 
X is a ratio, -we consider the relation X \, k, where k is the vector-family in 
question; or sometimes we consider X^Klt or sometimes X[, (*u Cnv"*). 
Concerning ratios with their fields thus limited, which are what we may 
call " applied'" ratios, we have to prove various propositions. 
(1) No two members of a family must have two different ratios. This 
is proved, for an open and connected family, in *350"44. 
(2) All ratios except 0g and oo q must be one-one relations when limited 
to a single family. This is proved, for an open and connected family, in 
*350'5; with the same hypothesis, 0g is one-many (*350'51). 
(3) The relative product of two applied ratios ought to be equal to the 
arithmetical product of the corresponding pure ratios with its field limited, 
i.e. if X, Y are ratios, we ought to have 
Xt« \Yt« =(XxsY)^K 
or Xt«l|Ft«l-(XxiF)t«,. 
That is to say, two-thirds of half a pound of .cheese ought to be (2/3 x«l/2) 
of a pound of cheese; and similarly in any other case. For any open connected 
family, we have (*35(r6) 
XtKt\YtKtG(Xx.Y)tKl, 
but in order to obtain an equation instead of an inclusion, it is necessary 
(*35131) that k should be " submultipliable," i.e. that if R is any member 
of k, and v any inductive cardinal other than zero, there should be a member 
of k whose i>th power is R. The class of such families is denoted by 
" FMsubm," and considered in *351. 

408 
QUANTITY 
[PART VI 
(4) If X, Y are ratios and T is a member of the family k, we ought 
to have 
(X t k'T)\(Yt k'T) = (X +s Y) t k'T, 
that is, two-thirds of a pound of cheese together with half a pound of cheese 
ought to be (2/3 +«1/2) of a pound of cheese, and similarly in any other 
instance. This property is shown, in #35143, to hold for any open connected 
submultipliable family in which all powers of members are members. In any 
open connected family, if R, S, Te k, we have 
RXT.SYT.3.(R\S)(X+SY)T (#350-62). 
The remainder of the hypothesis of *351-43 is required in order to prove 
(o) that X tk'T, Y^k'T and (X +s Y) tk'T exist, (b) that (X Ik'T) | (YIk'T), 
which is the R\S of #35062, is a member of k. As applied to *,, we have 
to take the representative (cf. *332) of the relative product; if L e «,, we have 
(#35142) 
rep„'{(X£«,'-&) 1(FD *'£)} -(*+. Y)t k*L, 
provided k is open and connected and submultipliable. 
The fact that the above propositions can be proved for suitable vector- 
families constitutes the reason for studying such families, as we did in 
Section B. The proof of the above propositions, together with other 
elementary properties of applied ratios, occupies the first two numbers of 
this Section. 
We proceed next (*352) to consider all the rational multiples of & given 
vector in a given family, i.e. all the members of a given family k which have, 
to a given vector T, a ratio which is a member of C'H', or, alternatively, all 
the members of /e, which have to T a ratio which is a member of C'Hg. It 
will be observed that, in virtue of *307, if R and S have a ratio X which is 
a member of C'H', R and S have the corresponding negative ratio X | Cnv. 
The members of k which have to T a ratio which is a member of C'H' are 
those vectors R for which we have 
(^X).XeC'H'.RXT, 
i.e. using the notation of *336, those for which we have 
(nX).XeC'H'.RATX. 
Thus they constitute the class 
k n AT"C'H'. 
Assuming that Tek, the vector which has the ratio X to T is k'] At'X. 
This is the vector whose measure is X when T is the unit. Thus k] At[C'H' 
is the correlator of a vector with its measure. It iB easy to prove (#35212) 
that k'] At\C'W is one-one. 

SECTION C] 
MEASUREMENT 
40.9 
We can arrange the vectors which are rational multiples of T in a series 
by correlation with their measures, putting vectors with smaller measures 
before those with larger measures. The ordering relation is TK, where 
TK = K1AT>H' Df. 
Similarly the members of /cc which are positive or negative rational multiples 
of T may be ordered by the relation TKl, where 
Tn = ^ATiH9 Df. 
We prove that change of units makes no difference to TK, i.e. if S is any 
member of k which is a rational multiple of T, then SK — TK (*35245). The 
corresponding proposition holds for TKi if S has a positive ratio to T, but if S 
has a negative ratio, Sa = TKK (*352-5657). 
If k is a serial family, TK is the converse of UK (cf. #336) with its field 
limited to rational multiples of T (*352'72). This proposition connects the 
generalized form of greater and less represented by UK with the form of 
greater and less derived from greater and less among the measures of vectors, 
since it shows that, in a serial family, the vectors which have greater measures 
come later in the series UK, and those with smaller measures come earlier. 
We next proceed (*353) to consider " rational" families. These are 
families in which every member is a rational multiple of some one unit T, 
i.e. in which 
(<zT).TeKs.KCAT"C'H'. 
It is obvious that, given any family, the rational multiples of one of its 
members constitute a rational sub-family. In a rational family, rationals 
are sufficient for measurement, and irrationals are not required. If the 
family has connexity, it will be serial; in fact, if T is one of its vectors and 
a is a member of its field, we have (cf. #3533233) 
UK = *1 AT'E'.s'kz^AJkI At>H'. 
Thus both UK and s'ks are ordinally similar to H'IAt"k. If k is sub- 
multipliable, UK is ordinally similar to H' (*353-44). 
We proceed next (*354) to consider " rational nets," which are important 
in connection with the introduction of coordinates in geometry. A rational 
net is obtained from a given family, roughly speaking, by selecting those 
vectors which are rational multiples of a given vector, and then limiting their 
fields to the points which can be reached by means of them from a given 
point. In order to make this more precise, we proceed as follows: Let us 
define as the "connection" of a with respect to k the class A„"k,, i.e. all the 
points which can be reached from a by a member of «,. We will now define 
as the " a-connected derivative of k " the class of relations obtained by limiting 
27 

410 
QUANTITY 
[PART VI 
the field of every member of k to the connection of a with respect to k. This 
class of relations we denote by cx„'*:, putting 
CXa'K=t (Aa"KL)"K Df. 
Instead of k, we take, in order to obtain a rational net, all the rational 
multiples (in k) of a given member T of k, i.e. G'TK. Then cxa'G'TK is a 
rational net, namely the rational net associated with the origin a and the 
unit vector T. 
In proving propositions concerning the rational net cxa'G'TK, we often 
require the hypothesis that k is a group. In order to avoid having to make 
this hypothesis concerning our original family, we construct a closely allied 
family, which is always a group when k is connected. This family, which we 
call Kg, is obtained from k by including the converses of those members of k, 
if any, whose domains are equal to their converse domains, i.e. we put 
«s=*uCnv"(«nD's'a"*) Df. 
Then if « is a connected family, k3 is a connected family which is a group 
(#3541416), and (tcg\ = «, (#35415). Then putting X = Kg, we take cxa'G'TK 
rather than cxa'G'TK as the rational net to be considered. If k is an open 
and connected family, this rational net is a family which is open, connected, 
rational, transitive and asymmetrical (#354'41). 
We proceed next (#356) to the application of real numbers to vector- 
families. For the application of real numbers, it is essential that our family 
should be serial. Given a serial family in which a given vector S is the limit 
(in the series UK) of a set of vectors which are rational multiples of another 
vector R, it is natural to take as the measure of S, with the unit Ry the limit 
of the measures of the vectors whose limit is S. It is convenient to take our 
real numbers in the relational form given in #314, i.e. if £ is a segment of H, 
we take s'£ as the corresponding real number. Thus positive real numbers 
are the class s"G'®, while positive and negative real numbers together with 
zero are the class s"G'®g. If feC'0, a vector which has to R a ratio which 
is a member of f has a measure which is less than s'%. The class of all such 
-» —» 
vectors is s'g'R, i.e. if X = s'%, it is X'R. The limit of such vectors in the 
series UK, if it exists, will naturally be taken as the vector whose measure is 
X. Remembering that UK proceeds from greater to smaller vectors, we see 
that the first vector which is greater than every member of X'R will be the 
—» 
lower limit of X'R with respect to VK. Hence, if we write XK'R for the 
vector whose measure with the unit R is X, we have 
XK'R = 'PTec(Ulc)'X'R. 
Hence we may take as our definition of XK 
XK = prec(UK)\X\-K Df. 
Then XK is an " applied " real number. 

SECTION C] 
MEASUREMENT 
411 
The properties to be proved concerning applied real numbers almost all 
require that the family to which they are applied should be serial and sub- 
multipliable, and most of them also require that Cdw's'k^ should be semi- 
Dedekindian. Assuming this, we can prove that, if X, Yes"C'@, XK \ K is 
one-one, and, with various hypotheses, 
(XtK)\{YtK) = (XxrY)lK C*356-31), 
XK\YK = (X xrY)K (*356-33), 
(XK'R) | (YK'R) = (X +r Y)K'R (*356-54). 
These are the essential properties required of measurement, as in the 
analogous case of ratios. 
We might proceed to consider "real" multiples of a given vector, and 
"real" nets. But these subjects have less importance than in the analogous 
case of rationals, and are therefore not discussed. 
The Section ends (*359) with a number on existence-theorems for vector- 
families. The most important of these are derived from rationals and real 
numbers. The family whose members are of the form (+sX)l C'H', where 
X eC'H', is initial, serial, and submultipliable (*35921). The family whose 
members are of the form (+p /a) £ G'®', where /j,eC'&, is initial, serial, and 
submultipliable, and has Cnv's'/eg= ©', so that Cnv's'/eg e semi Ded (*359-31). 
Finally we prove that the properties of families are unaffected by the 
application of correlators, whence it follows that, given any series P whose 
relation-number is i + r), or is & where & \-\-Q, tb^re is an initial serial 
submultipliable family k such that Cnv'i-'/eg = P. Such a family may be 
used for the measurement of distances in P. 
It is of some interest to observe that, given a suitable family k, ratios 
with their field limited to ks form a family whose field is Kg. In this family, 
the zero vector is (1/1) ^ "3, and the family is connected if k is a rational 
family. If we wish to obtain a serial family, we must limit ourselves to 
ratios not less than 1/1, i.e. to 
C«8"iV(i/i). 
This family is serial, and if we call it X, we have (with a suitable hypothesis) 
It is necessary, however, if we are to obtain a family, that our original family 
should be submultipliable, since otherwise we do not necessarily have 
d'X\, Kd- ks. For this reason, we cannot use the family of ratios without 
a frequent loss of generality in the resulting theorems. 
The theory of measurement developed in this Section is only applicable 
to open families. The application of ratio to cyclic families is more complicated 
and is considered separately in Section D

*351. SUBMULTIPLIABLE FAMILIES. 
Summary of #351. 
A "submultipliable" family is one in which any vector can be divided 
into v equal parts (where v is any inductive cardinal other than 0), i.e. in 
which, if R e k, there is a vector £ which is a member of k and is such that 
S'=R The definition is 
*35101. FM subm = 
FM n k {R e k . v e NC ind.- t'O . DB< v. (g£) .SeK.R = S"} Df 
In open families, such as we are considering in this Section, S will be unique 
when R and v are given. But in cyclic families, as we shall show in 
Section D, there will be v values of S. For example, let k be a family of 
angles. Then the vector-angle 2/j.nr/v has its i>th power equal to 2tt for any 
integral value of /a, since 2/j.tt is the same vector as 2tt; and 2^77-/1/ has v 
different values, since, considered as a vector, any angle 0 is identical with 
0+2tt. In the present Section, however, these complications are excluded, 
owing to the fact that we confine our attention to open families. 
In virtue of #337^27, a family is submultipliable if it is serial and 
Gnv's'icg is compact and semi-Dedekindian (#35111). 
When k is a family which is open, connected, and submultipliable, if 
Le Kt and /j. e NC ind — t'0, we have 
(gilf).v¥6«;i.rep/ilf'1 = Z (*351'2). 
Hence if X is any ratio (excluding 00 q, now and always henceforth), we 
have 
E!A'P«;/Z (*351-21). 
In order to obtain the same result for k, we have to assume that all power's 
of members of k are members of k (*351-22), but we can obtain the same 
result for k w Cnv"/e without this assumption (*35r221), because of *331'54, 
which shows that in any connected family all powers of members of «uCnv"« 
are members of k w Cnv"/e. 
In virtue of the above propositions, the propositions on products and 
sums of ratios, which in #350 only stated inclusions, now state identities. 
Thus if Z, YeC'H', we have 
{X t *.) I (Y t /O = (Z xs Y) t Kt (*35131), 
rep/{(Z t k.'L) \(Yt kSL)} = (Z +s F) t k?L (*351'42), 

SECTION C] SUBMULTIPLIABLE FAMILIES 419 
where Leu,; also 
rep«'{(X t kk'L)|(F£ «.'Z)} = (Z-, F)£ k'L (#351-45). 
The corresponding propositions for ratios confined to k instead of to k 
require the additional hypothesis s'Pot"* C k, because this hypothesis is 
required in #351-22; on the other hand, in the analogue of #351/42 "rep," 
does not appear, and we have (with the above hypothesis) 
(ZI k'R) \(Yl k'R) = (Z +, F) £ k'R (#351-43), 
where Rbk. For ratios confined to « u Cnv"« instead of to k, the  
corresponding result can be proved without the hypothesis s'Pot"* C k (#351'431). 
It will be observed that the hypothesis s'Pot"* C k is satisfied if k is a group, 
though it may also be satisfied when k is not a group. Since a transitive 
connected family is a group, a transitive connected family always satisfies 
s'Pot"* C k, as has been proved already (#334132).

*352. RATIONAL MULTIPLES OF A GIVEN VECTOR. 
Summary of #352. 
By a " rational multiple" of a given vector in a family k we mean, if we 
are dealing with k, any vector in the family which has to the given vector 
a relation which is a member of C'H', and if we are dealing with *,, we mean 
any member of /e, which has to the given member of *, a relation which is 
a member of C'Hg. We will call the former "rational /e-multiples" and the 
latter "generalized rational multiples." It will be observed that if k contains 
pairs of members which are each other's converses, only one member of such 
a pair can be contained among the rational /e-multiples of a given member 
of k, provided k is an open family. Hence the rational /e-mnltiples of a given 
vector all have one "sense," even if this was not the case with the original 
family. 
Rational multiples of a given vector T can be arranged in a series by 
correlation with their measures with T as unit. These measures are ordered, 
in the case of rational /e-multiples, by the relation H', and in the case of 
generalized rational multiples, by the relation Hg. Moreover if X is the 
measure of a given member of k with T as unit, the given member of k is 
*1 AT'X; while if X is the measure of a given member of «,, the given 
member of/e, is k,1] At'X. Hence the rational /e-multiples of T are ordered 
by the relation /e"] AT'H', and the generalized rational multiples are ordered 
by the relation k,'] AT>Hg. These two relations, therefore, are the relations 
we shall consider in this number. We put 
#362-01. Tk=k\ AT>H' Df 
#35202. T^^K^A^Hg Df 
We assume throughout this number that k is open and connected. In 
dealing with TK, we assume 2'e*a> an(^ m dealing with TKl, we assume 
Te «j. We then prove the following propositions among others: 
K^AT\C'H'e\^>\ («352-12), 
K^A^C'Hgel-*! (#352-15), 
i.e. the relation of a rational multiple of T to its measure is onerone. 

424 QUANTITY [PART VI 
r„T„eSer (#352-16-17). 
Observe that this requires only that k should be open and connected. The 
serial property results from the correlation with H' or Hg. 
C'TK = «n AT«C'H'. C'TKi = *. ft AT"C'H„ (#3523-31). 
If Sis any non-zero member of C'TK, C'SK = C'TK (#352-41), i.e. the rational 
/e-multiples of T are the same as those of any rational /^-multiple of T\ with 
a similar proposition for C'TKl (#352-42). 
RTKS. = : R,Se k ft AT'<C'H': (^fi,v).fi,v e NC ind.^ <V.R" = S" («352-43). 
This is a convenient formula for TK, and leads immediately to 
TK = {a'H''(l/l)} £.(« n AT"C'H') (#35244). 
—» 
Observe that H"(l/l) is the class of rational proper fractions, including 0,. 
By #352-44 and #352-41-3, we see that, if S+ I |\s'(I"*:, 
8e C'TK ,D.SK = TK (#352-45), 
i.e. the order of magnitude of a set of vectors which are rational /e-multiples 
of a given unit is independent of the choice of the unit. 
In order to establish the analogous property for TKl, we first prove a 
formula analogous to ^352-44, namely 
Tu = Cnv;{s'Jf?'(lA)} t («. ft AT"C'H) $ 
[i'H"{l/l)}t(KtnAT"CH') (#352-54). 
Here the first term gives the. series of negative multiples of T, while the 
second gives the series of positive multiples of T (including I f s'(1"k). 
From the above formula it follows, as in the case of TK1 that if S is a 
positive multiple of T (not including I[s'Q."k), SKl=TKl, while if S is a 
negative multiple of T, SKl = Tu (#352-56-57). 
Finally we deal with the relation of UK to TK. Here we have to assume 
that k is a serial family. We then find that UK with its field confined to 
rational /e-multiples of T is the converse of TK, i.e. we have 
#35272. \-iKeFMar.TeKd.3. U^G'T^k^ AT'<H'=TK 
#35201. TK^K)ATiH' Df 
#35202. TKl = Kl^AT'>Hg Df 
•3521. \-:.RTKS. = :R,SeK:('S.X,Y).XHr\T.RXT.SYT [(#352-01)] 
#35211. V :. RTUS .-=: R,Se Kl: (gX H ■ XH« Y- RXT.SYT [(#352-02)] 

SECTION C] RATIONAL MULTIPLES OF A GIVEN VECTOR 425 
#35212. \-:iceFMa,p conx . Teicd.Z> . k} At\ C'H' e 1 -> 1 
Dem.
