SECTION B 
ADDITION, MULTIPLICATION AND EXPONENTIATION 
Summary of Section B. 
In the present section, we have to consider the arithmetical operations as 
applied to cardinals, as well as the relation of greater and less between 
cardinals. Thus the topics to be dealt with in this section are the first that 
can properly be said to belong to Arithmetic. 
The treatment of addition, multiplication and exponentiation to be given 
in what follows is guided by the desire to secure the greatest possible 
generality. In the first place, everything to be said generally about the 
arithmetical operations must apply equally to finite and infinite classes or 
cardinals. In the second place, we desire such definitions as shall allow the 
number of summands in a sum or of factors in a product to be infinite. In the 
third place, we wish to be able to add or multiply two numbers which are not 
necessarily of the same type. In the fourth place, we wish our definitions to 
be such that the sum of the cardinal numbers of two or more classes shall 
depend only upon the cardinal numbers of those classes, and shall be the same 
when the classes overlap as when they are mutually exclusive; with similar 
conditions for the product. The desire to obtain definitions fulfilling all these 
conditions leads to somewhat more complicated definitions than would  
otherwise be required; but in the outcome, the result is simpler than if we started 
with simpler definitions, since we avoid vexatious exceptions. 
The above observations will become clearer through their applications. 
Let us begin with the case of arithmetical addition of two classes. 
If a and ft are mutually exclusive classes, the sum of their cardinal 
numbers will be the cardinal number of au/3. But in order that a and ft 
may be mutually exclusive, they must have no common members, and this is 
only significant when they are of the same type. Hence, given two perfectly 
general classes a and ft, we require to find two classes which are mutually 
exclusive and are respectively similar to a and ft; if these two classes are 
called a and ft', then Nc'(a' u ft1) will be the sum of the cardinal numbers of 
a and ft. We note that Ana and An ft indicate respectively the A's of the 
same types as a and ft, and accordingly we take as a' and ft' the two classes 
I (A n ft)"i"a and (A n a) I "i"ft; 
these two classes are always of the same type, always mutually exclusive, and 
always similar to a and ft respectively. Hence we define 
a + ft = l(Anft)"i"av(Ana)l"i"j3 Df. 

64 
CARDINAL ARITHMETIC 
[PART III 
The snm of the cardinal numbers of a and /3 will then be the cardinal 
number of a + $; hence we may call a + /3 the arithmetical class-sum of two 
classes, in contradistinction to auj3, which is the logical sum. It will be 
noted that a + /3, unlike auft does not require that a and $ should be of the 
same type. Also a + a is not identical with a, but when a = A, a + a is also A, 
though in a different type. Thus the law of tautology does not hold of the 
arithmetical class-sum of two classes. 
If fx and v are two cardinals of assigned types, we denote their arithmetical 
sum by fi + cv. (As many kinds of arithmetical addition occur in our work, 
and as it is essential to our purpose to distinguish them, we effect the  
distinction by suffixes to the sign of addition. It is, of course, only in dealing 
with principles that these different symbols are needed: we do not wish to 
suggest that they should be adopted in ordinary mathematics.) Now if p + cv 
is to have the properties which we commonly associate with the sum of two 
cardinals, it must be typically ambiguous, and must be the cardinal number 
of any class which can be divided into two mutually exclusive parts having 
p terms and v terms respectively. Hence we are led to the following definition: 
/" + C* = i{<&«, $) • h- = N»c'« ■ " = Noc',9 .?sm(a + /8)} Df. 
In this definition, various points should be noted. In the first place, it 
does not require that /x and v should be of the same type; fx +c v is significant 
whenever fx and v are classes of classes. Thus it is not necessary for  
significance that fx and v should be cardinals, though if they are not both cardinals, 
/x + c v = A. If they are both cardinals, we find 
/". +o ^ = £ {(a«, $) • a e ^ . $ e v . £ sm (a + $)}. 
Thus in this case aefj,.$ev.'D.a + $e/x+cv. 
Hence if neith^- /x nor v is null, and if a has fj, terms and /9 has v terms, 
a + /9 is a member of p +c v. It easily follows that 
I-: fx. = N0c'a. v = N0c'/3.3.^+^ = Nc'(a + /9). 
Hence when ^ and v are homogeneous cardinals (i.e. when they are cardinals 
other than A), their sum is the number of the arithmetical class-sum of any 
two classes having jj, terms and v terms respectively. 
A few words are necessary to explain why, in the definition, we put 
,u = N0c'a. i> = N0c'/3 rather than ^ = Nc'a. v = Nc',9. The reason is this. 
Suppose either y, or v, say fi, is A. Then, by *102-73, /j. = Nc (£)'*'?, if K is of 
the appropriate type. Hence if we had put 
^+0^=1 {(aa, $).11 = Nc'a. v = Nc'£. £ sm (a + $)} Df, 
where the ambiguities of type involved in Nc'a and Nc'/9 may be determined 
as we please, we should have 
v=-Ncl$.^.t^ + $efi+cv, 
i-e- v = Nc'$.'2.t'S+$eA+ev. 

SECTION B] ADDITION, MULTIPLICATION AND EXPONENTIATION 65 
We should also have t't'% + 0e A+0v and so on. Thus A+0i> would not 
have a definite value, i.e. it would not merely have typical ambiguity, which 
it ought to have, but it would not have a definite value even when its type 
was assigned. Thus such a definition would be unsuitable. For the above 
reasons, we put fj, = N0c'a. i> = N0c'/3 in the definition, and obtain the typical 
ambiguity which we desire by means of the typical ambiguity of the "sm" 
in "£sm(a + /S)." It is always essential to right symbolism that the values 
of typically ambiguous symbols should be unique as soon as their type is 
assigned. The scope of these definitions and of the corresponding definitions 
for multiplication and exponentiation (*113'04-05 . *116-0304) is extended 
by convention IIT of the prefatory statement. 
The above definition of p +c v is designed for the case in which /i and v 
are typically definite. But we must be able to speak of" Nc'7+0 Nc'8," and 
this must be a definite cardinal, namely Nc'(7 + 8). If we simply write 
Nc'7, Nc'8 in place of fx, v in the definition of fj,+cv, we find 
Nc'7 +0 Nc'8 = I {(a«, /3). Nc'7 = N0c'a . Nc'8 = Noc'jS. £ sm (a + 0)}. 
But this will not always have a definite value when the type of Nc'7 +0 Nc'8 
is assigned. To take a simple case, write t'£ for 7 and i'y for 8. Then 
NcV£ +c Nc'i'y = f {(go, 0). Nc'i'f = N0c'a. No'i'y = Noc'jS. £ sm (a + 0)}, 
whence we easily obtain 
Nc'*'£+C Nc'i'y = i{(a«). Nc'i'f = N0c'a. J sm (a + i'y)}. 
If we determine the ambiguity of Nc'i'f to be N^'i'f, we find 
NcV?+0Nc'i'y = A 
in all types; but if we determine the ambiguity to be N0c'£'f, we have 
Nc V£ +c Nc'i'y = Nc'(£'f + I'y), 
and this exists in the type of t'£ + i'y, if not in lower types. Hence the value 
of Nc'i'f+0Nc't'y depends upon the determination of the ambiguity ofNc'i'f. 
It is obvious that we want our definition to yield 
Nc'7+cNc'8=Nc'(7 + 8) 
in all types; but in order to insure that this shall hold even when, for some 
values of f, Nc(f)'7 = A, we must introduce two new definitions, namely 
Nc'a +c /"• = N0c'a +c p Df, 
/Li+cNc'a=/Li+cN0c'a Df, 
whence h : Nc'a +0 Nc'/S = N0c'a +c N0c'/S = Nc'(a + 0). 
This definition is to be applied when "Nc'7" and "Nc'8" occur without any 
determination of type. On the other hand, if we have Nc(f)'7 and Nc(i7)'8, 
we apply the definition of /i +0 v. We shall find that whenever Nc (Q'y and 
Nc (17/8 both exist, 
Nc (0'7 +c Nc (1,)¾ = N„c'7 +0 N0c'8. 
Thus the above definition is only required in order to exclude values of £ or 17 
for which either Nc (f)*7 or Nc (rj)'S is A. 
b&w 11 5 

66 
CARDINAL ARITHMETIC 
[PART III 
The commutative and associative laws of arithmetical addition are easily 
deduced from the definition of a + 8. We shall have 
h.a+/S = Cnv"(/S + a), 
whence h . Nc'a +0 Nc',9 = Nc'/3 +0 Nc'a, 
because each = Nc'(a + B). A similar though slightly longer proof shows that 
I-. (a + 0) + 7 sm a + (8 + 7), 
whence h. (Nc'a +0 Nc',9) +0 Nc'7 = Nc'a +0 (Nc'B +0 Nc'7). 
The above definition of a + /9 enables us to proceed to the sum of any 
finite number of classes, and allows any one class to recur in the summation. 
But it does not enable us to define the sum of an infinite number of classes. 
For this we need a new definition. Since an infinite number of classes cannot 
be given by enumeration, but only by intension, we shall have to take a class 
of classes *, and define the arithmetical sum of the members of *. Thus now 
the classes which are the summands must all be of the same type (since they 
are all members of *), and no one class can occur more than once, since each 
member of * only counts once. (In order to deal with repetition, we must 
advance to multiplication, which will be explained shortly.) Thus in removing 
the limitation to a finite number of summands, we introduce certain othei 
limitations. This is the reason which makes it worth while to introduce the 
above definition of a + /9 in addition to the definition now to be given. 
If k. is a class of classes, the sum of the cardinal numbers of the members 
of * will evidently be obtained by constructing a class of mutually exclusive 
classes whose members have a one-one relation to the members of corresponding 
members of k. Suppose a, /9 are two different members of /e, and suppose x is 
a member both of a and of /9. Then we wish to count x twice over, once as a 
member of a and once as a member of /9. The simplest way to do this is to 
form the ordinal couples x |, a and x |, /9, which are not identical except when 
a and /3 are identical. Thus if we take all such ordinal couples, i.e. if we take 
the class ^ 
R {(ga?). x e a . R = x J, a}, 
for every a which is a member of k, we get a class of mutually exclusive 
classes, namely the classes of the form |, a"a, where a e /c, and each of these is 
similar to the corresponding member of k. Hence the logical sum of this class 
of classes, i.e. 
R {(ga, x).aeK.xea.R = xla], 
has the required number of terms. Now, by #85601, 
J,a"a = eJ'a. 
Hence the class whose logical sum we are taking is ej"/«r. Hence we put 
2'* = s'eJ"* Df. 
%'k may be called the arithmetical sum of k, in contradistinction to s'/c, which 
is the logical sum. Thus 2'* bears to s'k a relation analogous to that which 
a + /9 bears to a u 0. 

SECTION B] ADDITION, MULTIPLICATION AND EXPONENTIATION 67 
We put further 2Nc'* = Nc's'eJ"* Df. 
Thus SNc'/e is the sum of the numbers of members of k. 
It is to be observed that 2Nc'/e is not in general a function of Nc"/e. For, 
if two members of * have the same cardinal number, this will only count once 
in Nc"«, whereas it counts twice in SNc'at. 
We shall find that, provided a=j=/S, 
2Nc'(t'a u 1'ft) = Nc'a +0 Nc'£. 
Thus where a finite number of summands are concerned, the two definitions 
of addition agree, except that the first allows one class to count several times 
over, while the second does not. 
In dealing with multiplication, our procedure is closely analogous to the 
procedure for addition. We first define the arithmetical class-product of two 
classes a and ft, which is a certain class whose cardinal number is the product 
of the cardinal numbers of a and ft. We write ft x a for the arithmetical 
class-product of ft and a, and define it as the class of all ordinal couples of 
which the referent is a member of a and the relatum a member of ft, i.e. as 
-# {(a*' y)-coea.yeft.R = x],y). 
By *40-7, this class is s'a I "ft. Hence we put 
ftxa = s'al"ft Df. 
The class a 1 "ft is similar to ft, and each member of it is similar to a; hence 
if N0c'a = /Li and ^0'$ = v, s'al "ft consists of v classes having p members 
each. The class a I "ft is important also in connection with exponentiation. 
The product of two cardinals is defined as follows: 
/" x0 ».=■ I'{(•&«> £) ■ 1* = N0c'a. v = NoC'jS. £ sm (a x ft)} D£ 
In regard to types, this definition calls for analogous remarks to those which 
were made on p +0 v. Also, as before, we need definitions of fi x0 Nc'a and 
Nc'a x0 ft, whence we obtain 
Nc'a x0 Nc'£ = N0c'a x0 Noc',9 Df. 
By means of these definitions, we can define the product of any finite number 
of cardinals; but in order to define products which have an infinite number of 
factors, we need a new definition. 
If k is a class of classes, we take ea'/e as its arithmetical product. In simple 
cases, it is easy to see the justification of this decision. E.g. let * consist of 
the three classes 0^,0,,0¾. and let the members of ax be %l,%2; those o{ae,yl,y2) 
those of 03, zu z2. Then the members of e^K are

Nc'^'j: = 8 = Nc'oii x0 Nc'a, x„ Nc'oij. In general, however, the existence of 
e^K is doubtful, owing to the doubt as to the validity of the multiplicative 
axiom. (We shall return to this point shortly.) Hence there is no proof that 
the product of an infinite number of factors cannot be zero unless one of the 
factors is zero. 
When k is a class of mutually exclusive classes, e4'« is similar to D"e±'/c.

Thus for products of a finite number of different factors, the two definitions of 
multiplication agree. 
It remains to define exponentiation. Since this is not a commutative 
operation, it essentially involves an order as between the base and the  
exponent; hence we do not obtain a definition of the exponentiation of a class k, 
analogous to 2Nc'« or nNc'«, but only a definition of fi", which may be extended 
to any finite number of exponentiations. We put 
a exp 0 = Prod'a J, "# Df, 
where a 1 "@ has the meaning explained above, resulting from #3803. It will

/*"=■£ {(3«. /8) ■ M =■ N«c'a ■ v = NoC'jS. J sm (a exp /8)} Df,

(Nc'a)" = (N0c'a)" Df and ^Nc'o = ^n.c'0 Df. 
The above definition of exponentiation gives the same value of p" as results 
from Cantor's definition by means of "Belegungen." The class of Cantor's 
"Belegungen" is 
& {R e 1 -> Cls. D'j? C a . 0.'B = 0\, 
Le- («T/8V/8. 
and it is easily proved that this is similar to a exp /3. 
The usual formal properties of exponentiation result without much difficulty 
from the above definitions. 

SECTION B] ADDITION, MULTIPLICATION AND EXPONENTIATION 69 
The above definition of exponentiation is so framed as to make  
propositions on exponentiation independent of the multiplicative axiom, except 
when exponentiation is to be connected with multiplication, i.e. when it is to 
be shown that the product of v factors, each of which is p, is pr. This 
proposition cannot be proved generally without the multiplicative axiom. 
Similarly, in the theory of multiplication, the proposition that the sum of 
v /li's is p x0v requires the multiplicative axiom (as does also the proposition 
that a product is zero when and only when one of its factors is zero).  
Otherwise, the theory of multiplication proceeds without the need for employing 
the multiplicative axiom. 
To take first the connection of addition and multiplication: this  
connection, in the form in which we naturally suppose it to hold, is affirmed in the 
proposition: 
fj., KeNC. Kev r\ Clsexcl'/Li . D . s'/cep x0v (A) 
or fi, v eNC. Kev ri CIV ■ 3 ■ 2'*e/u X^.

It will be seen that, in the above use of the multiplicative axiom, we have

"smsm" in the present section. 
We treat also, in this section, the relation of greater and less between 
cardinals. We say that Nc'a > Nc'/3 when there is a part of a which is 
similar to /3, but no part of /3 is similar to a. The principal proposition in 
this subject is the Schroder-Bernstein theorem, i.e. 
I" i fJb^V .V^ (JL.O . (J, = V. 
This is an immediate consequence of *73-88. It cannot be shown, without 
assuming the multiplicative axiom, that of any two cardinals one must be the 
greater, i.e. 
/j,,ve NC . fx^v .D\ fji>v .v .v> fx. 
If we assume the multiplicative axiom, this results from Zermelo's proof that 
on that assumption, every class can be well-ordered, together with Cantor's 
proof that of any two well-ordered series which are not similar, one must be 
similar to a part of the other. But these propositions cannot be proved till a 
much later stage (#258). 

*110. THE ARITHMETICAL SUM OF TWO CLASSES AND OF 
TWO CARDINALS 
Summary q/*110. 
In this number, we start from the definition: 
*110Ol. « + /8=l(An/8)"t"«w(An«)l"t"j8 Df 
a+ /8 is called the "arithmetical class-sum" of a and /3. The definition is 
framed so as to give tw# mutually exclusive classes respectively similar to a 
and /3, so that the number of terms in the logical sum of these two classes is 
the arithmetical sum of the numbers of terms in a and /3 respectively, a + /3 
is significant whenever a and /3 are classes, whatever their types may be. 
By means of a + /3, we define the arithmetical sum of two cardinals as 
follows: 
*11002. /*+e»-f{(a«,/8)./* = N^«.» = N^/8.f8m(« + /8)} Df 
This defines the " arithmetical sum of two cardinals." (It is not necessary 
to significance that fx and v should be cardinals, but only that they should be 
classes of classes. If, however, either is not a cardinal, /x+0v = A.) It will 
be observed that, when /x and v are typically definite, so are a and /3 in the 
above definition; but f is typically ambiguous, on account of the ambiguity 
of " sm." Hence fx +e v is also typically ambiguous. 
It will be shown that fx +0 v is always a cardinal, and that, if 
fi = N0c'a. v = Ncc'/3, then ^ +0 v = Nc'(a + /3). 
Hence whenever fi and v are cardinals other than A, fx+ev is an existent 
cardinal in some types, though it may be A in others. 
Two more definitions are required in this number, namely: 
*11003. Nc'a+0/u, = N0c'a+o/u, Df 
*110 04. M+0Ne'« = M+eNoC'« Df 
These definitions are needed in order to apply the definition of fa+0v to 
the case in which /x and v are replaced by typically ambiguous symbols' 
Nc'a and Nc'/3. It does not make any difference to the value of Nc'a +0 Nc'/3 
how the ambiguities of Nc'a and Nc'/3 are determined, so long as they are 
determined in a way that insures g ! Nc'a . g ! Nc'/3; but if there are types 
in which either Nc'a or Nc'/3 is A, we get Nc'a +0 Nc'/3 = A in all types if we 
determine the ambiguities so that Nc'a = A or Nc'/3=A. It is in order to 
exclude such determinations of the ambiguity that the above definitions are 
required. Also in connection with these definitions and the corresponding 
definitions *113-04-05 and *116-03-04 and *ll7-02-03, the convention IIT of 
the prefatory statement must be noted.

The propositions of the present number begin with the properties of a + /3. 
We show (#110'iri2) that a + /3 consists of two mutually exclusive parts,

8 are respectively similar to a and /3, then 7 + 8 is similar to a + /3. We show

mutually exclusive parts which are respectively similar to a and /3.

be null when p and v exist.

this number except #110'4.

have been more difficulty in dealing with types, and because the existence of 
Nc'a +0 Nc'/3 (in the types in which it does exist) is less evident with the 
above definition than with the definitions given in #110-01-02-03-04.

hypothesis /1, v eNC in such propositions as the commutative and associative 
laws.

When /i is a typically definite cardinal, sm"/i is the same cardinal 
rendered typically ambiguous; when p is a typically ambiguous cardinal, 
am"fj, is ^. In place of the above proposition, we might write 
/aeNC. 3. fj,+o0 — fj,; this would be true whenever the ambiguity of

gives more information. 
#11061. h. Nc'a +00 = Nc'a 
Dem. 
h . #1011. 3 h. Nc'a +0 0 = Nc'a +0 Nc'A 
[#110-32] =Nc'(awA) 
[#24-24] = Nc'a.31-. Prop 
In this proposition, Nc'a is typically ambiguous; hence we escape the 
necessity of putting sm"Nc'a on the right, as we should have to do if 
Nc'a were typically definite. We can deduce #110-61 from #110-6 as 
follows: 
I-. #110-3 .31-. Nc'a +„ 0 = N0c'a +0 0 
[#110-6] =sm"N0c'a 
[#103-4] = Nc'a 
We have to travel via N0c'a in this proof, in order to avoid the possibility 
of a typical determination of Nc'a which would make Nc'a = A. It is for 
the same reason that we cannot put "sm"Nc'a = Nc'a"; for if the first 
Nc'a is determined to a type in which Nc'a = A, while the second is not, this 
equation becomes false.

[#52-1.#51-211] = £ ((37, y).ye sm"^. y~e 7. f = 7 wi'yj: D h . Prop 
The proposition 
/ieNC . D . /u, +01 = f{(37,y) .76/1. y~e7 . f sm7 w t'y} 
which might at first sight seem demonstrable, will only be true universally if 
the total number of objects in any one type is not finite. For suppose a is a 
type, and \x, = N0c'a. Then if a is a finite class, /j, = i'u. Hence 7 e fi . Dy>v . y e 7. 
Hence f {(37,^) . 76^ . y~e<y. gsm (7 ^ i'y)} = A in all types. But fi+cl will 
exist in all types higher than that of 7. If on the other hand the number of 
entities in a is infinite, we shall have 
y ea. D. a— i'y eNc'a. y~e a — i'y. 
Hence in this case the above proposition will be true universally.

6—2 

*111. DOUBLE SIMILARITY 
Summary of *111. 
The arithmetical properties of a class, so far as these do not require or 
assume that it is a class of classes, are the same for any similar class. But a 
class of classes has many arithmetical properties which it does not share with 
all similar classes of classes. For example, if k is a class of classes, the number 
of members of s'k is an arithmetical property of *, but it is obvious that this 
is not determined by the number of members of *, but requires also a  
knowledge of the numbers of members of members of k. For example, let k consist 
of the two members a and fa and let X consist of y and 8. Then *sm X; but 
in order to be able to infer s'/esms'X, we require *, XeCls2excl and 
a sm y . /3 sm 8 or a sm 8 . /3 sm y or some such further datum. The relation of 
"double similarity," to be defined in the present number, is a relation between 
classes of classes, which, when it holds between k and X, insures that all the 
arithmetical properties of k and X are the same, e.g. we have (in particular) 
Nc's'« = NcVX and Nc'ea'tf =Nc'6a'X. This relation we denote by "smsm," 
which is to be read as one symbol. It is defined as follows: We define first the 
class of "double correlators" of k and X, which we denote by "/esmsmX," and 
of which the definition is 
#111-01. *smsmX = (l-*l)n d's'XnT(K= Te"\) Df 
so that 
\-\TeKsmsm\.= .Tel^l .d'T= s'\. K=Te"\. 
We then define "«sm sm X" as meaning that k sm sin X is not null, i.e. that 
there is at least one double correlator of* and X, 
To illustrate the nature of a double correlator, let us suppose that k consists 
of the two classes a, and 0¾. and that 0¾ consists of xu, xn, while a, consists of 
^21, 0^22) X<ft. Similarly let X consist of /3, and fa, while /3, consists of yu> yn 
and fa consists of yiu y^, yw. Now let T correlate each x with the y having 
the same two suffixes. Then T is a one-one, and its converse domain is s'X. 
Moreover Tt'fa (which is T"fa) = a1, and 2Vft = a,,so that Te"\ = /c. Thus 
T is a double correlator according to the definition. 
The essential characteristic of a double correlator T is that (1) T is a 
correlator of s'k and s'X, (2) Te fX is a correlator of k and X. If we write S 
in place of Te\~\, then if /SeX, we have S'ffe/c; moreover T^fi is a correlator 
of S'@ and fa Thus k and X are similar classes of similar classes. They are 
not merely this, however, for we not only know that S'/S is similar to /3, but 

SECTION B] 
DOUBLE SIMILARITY 
85 
we know a particular correlator of S'ft and #, namely T\~/3. This is essential 
to the use of double similarity, as will appear shortly. 
Let us consider the relation between k and X which consists in their being 
similar classes of similar classes. This means that there is a correlator 8 of /e 
and X, such that, if /S e X, S'ff is similar to /3. That is to say, we are to consider 
the hypothesis 
faS).S el->l.jyS-K.CL'S-\.S Gam 
or, as it may be more briefly expressed, 
a I k sm X n Rl'sm. 
Let us assume SexsmXn Rl'sm. If we attempt to prove (say) that s'k 
is similar to s'X, we find that we are forced to assume the multiplicative axiom, 
unless k and X are finite. This necessity arises as follows. Let us put 
Crp (Syfi = (8'fi) am 0, 
where "Crp" stands for "correspondence." Then we know that whenever 
/S e X, Crp (S)'/3 is not null. Further it is easy to prove that, if k and X are 
classes of mutually exclusive classes, and if we can pick out one representative 
member of Crp^'/S for each value of /S which is a member of X, then the 
relational sum of all these representative correlations gives us a correlator of 
s'k and s'X. That is, we have 
r : *, X eClsaexcl .SeKsmXn Rl'sm . i?eeA'Crp(S)"X.D.s'D'i?e(s'*)sm(s'X). 
But in order to infer hence s'k sm s'X, we need g ! eA'Crp (S)"X, i.e. we 
need to be able to pick out a particular correlator for each pair of similar 
classes S'/3 and /S. This, however, cannot be done in general without assuming 
the multiplicative axiom. It follows that we must not define two classes as 
having double similarity when j!*anXn Rl'sm, but must give a definition 
which enables us to specify a particular correlator for each pair of similar 
classes. This is what is effected by the above definition of double correlators, 
where our S is given as of the form Te [X, where Te 1 -> 1. Q'T= s'X. If the 
multiplicative axiom is assumed, but in general not otherwise, we have 
(*111'5) _ 
K,Xe Clsa excl. D: k sm sm X . = . g ! k sm X n Rl'sm. 
In the present number, we shall begin with various properties of double 
correlators. We prove (#11111) that T is a double correlator of /c and X when, 
and only when, T is a correlator of s'k and s'X, and Te \"X is a correlator of k 
and X. We prove (#111112) that in the same hypothesis, Te f X e * sm Xn Rl'sm. 
We prove (#11113) that If-s'X is a double correlator of X with itself; that 
(#111131) if T is a double correlator of * and X, T is a double correlator of X 
and *; that (#111132) if S, T are double correlators of k with X and of X with 
fi respectively, S\ T is a double correlator of k with ^. Hence it follows 
(*111'45-451'4<52) that double similarity is reflexive, symmetrical, and  
transitive.

[#111-52-5] 

*112. THE ARITHMETICAL SUM OF A CLASS OF CLASSES 
Summary o/#112. 
In this number, we return to the arithmetical operations. The definition 
of addition in #110 was only applicable to a finite number of summands, 
because the summands had to be enumerated. In the present number, we 
define the arithmetical sum of a class of classes, so that the summands are 
given as the members of a class, and do not require to be enumerated. Hence 
the definition in this number is as applicable to an infinite number of summands 
as to a finite number. 
If at is a class of mutually exclusive classes, the number of s'k will be the 
sum of the numbers of members of at; i.e. if we write "SNc'at" for the sum of 
the numbers of members of k, 
k, e Clsa excl. D . Nc's'« = 2Nc'*. 
But when the members of k. are not mutually exclusive, a term x which is a 
member of two members (say a and /9) of /c has to be counted twice over in 
obtaining the arithmetical sum of /c, whereas in the logical sum x is only 
counted once. Thus we need a construction which shall duplicate x, taking 
it first as a member of a, and then as a member of /9. This is effected if we 
replace x first by a; 4 a, and then by x I /3. In fact, a; ^, a has the kind of 
arithmetical properties which we mean to secure when we speak of "x  
considered as a member of a"—a phrase which, as it stands, does not serve our 
purpose, for x is simply x however we may choose to consider it. Thus we 
replace a by I a"a and /9 by J, #"/9 and so on; i.e. (using #85-5), we replace 
a by e J a and fit by e J /9 and so on. These new classes are similar to a and /9 
and so on, and are mutually exclusive. Hence their logical sum has the 
number of terms which is wanted for the arithmetical sum of the members of 
k. Thus we put 
2'/c = s'el"/c Df, 
2Nc'*=Nc'2'* Df. 
With regard to the second of these definitions, it is to be observed that 
SNc'tf is not a function of Nc'Se, unless no two members of at are similar; for 
Nc"*r cannot contain the same number twice over. For the same reason, if X 
is a class of cardinals, and we define "Sum'X," we do not get what is wanted 
for arithmetical addition, because our definition will not enable us to deal 
with summations in which there are numbers that are repeated. We could, 
if it were worth while, define "Sum'X " as follows: Take a class of classes /e, 
consisting of one class having each number which is a member of X, i.e. let k 

94 CARDINAL ARITHMETIC [PART III 
be a selection from X; then %'k will have the required number of terms. I.e. 
we might put 
Sum'X = f {(a*). * e D"e4'X . f sm £<*} Df. 
But since this definition is only available for sums in which no number is 
repeated, it is not worth while to introduce it. 
In this number we prove the following propositions among others. 
#112-15. hfte Clsa excl. D . s'/c e 2Nc'* 
This is an extension of #110-32. 
*112'17. h : * sm sm X. D. 2Nc'/e = 2Nc'X. Vk sm 2'X 
The chief point in the above proposition is that it does not require 
k, XeClsaexcl. 
#112-2—-24 are concerned with the use of the multiplicative axiom and 
the propositions of #111 in which it appears as hypothesis. We have 
#11222. V :. Mult ax . D : g ! (ej"/«r)sm(e J"X) n Rl'sm. D. 2Nc'* = SNc'X 
whence we derive the proposition 
#112-24- V :. Mult ax . D : p, v e NC. *, X e fi n CIS. D . 2Nc'/«r = XNc'X 
I.e. assuming the multiplicative axiom, two classes which each consist of 
p classes of v terms each have the same number of terms in their sum. This 
number would naturally be defined as fi multiplied by v, but owing to the 
necessity of the multiplicative axiom in this proposition, we have selected a 
different definition of multiplication (#113) which does not depend upon the 
multiplicative axiom. The reader should observe that the similarity of two 
classes, each of which consists of fi mutually exclusive sets of v terms, cannot 
be proved in general without the multiplicative axiom. 
The remaining propositions of this number give properties of 2 in special 
cases. We prove that 2'A= A (#112'3), that 2NcVa = Nc'a(*112'321), that 
a + £. D . 2Nc'(t'a w t'/3)=Nc'a +0Nc'£ (#112-34), which connects the  
definition of addition in this number with that in #110. Finally we prove the 
general associative law for addition, in the following two forms:

[*85'601] = e I (T"/3) :31-. Prop 
In the following proposition, we have a double correlator of a sort which 
will frequently occur in cardinal arithmetic, namely T\\ Te with its converse 
domain limited, where T is a given double correlator (or single correlator, on 
other occasions). As appears from the propositions used in the above proof of 
#112152, if T is a correlator whose converse domain includes fH and has y as 
a member, (T || Te)'(y I/3) = (T'y) 4 (T«0). Thus T\\Tt is an operation which, 
when operating on suitable relations of individuals to classes (including  
selectors), turns the individuals into their correlates and the classes into the classes 
of their members' correlates. This is why it is a useful relation.

This proposition establishes the agreement of the two definitions of 
addition, namely that in #110 and that in #112. It will be seen that the 
definition of #112 is inapplicable to the addition of a class to itself, if this 
is to give the double of the class, instead of (like logical addition) simply 
reproducing the class. Hence the need of the condition a ^/3 in the above 
proposition.

*113. ON THE ARITHMETICAL PRODUCT OF TWO CLASSES 
OR OF TWO CARDINALS 
Summary q/"*113. 
In this number, we give a definition of multiplication which can be 
extended to any finite number of factors, but not to an infinite number of 
factors. We define first the arithmetical class-product of two classes a and ft, 
and thence the product of two cardinals fx and v as the number of terms in the 
product of a and ft when a has \x, terms and ft has v terms. In #114, we shall 
give a definition of multiplication which is not restricted to a finite number 
of factors. The advantages of the definition to be given in this number are, 
that it does not require the factors to be of the same type, and that it enables 
us to multiply a class by itself without (as in logical addition and  
multiplication) simply reproducing the class in question. The disadvantage of the 
definition in this number is the impossibility of extending it to an infinite 
number of factors. 
The arithmetical class-product of two classes a and ft, which we denote by 
ft x a*, is the class of all ordinal couples which take their referent from a and 
their relatum from ft, i.e. it is the class of all such relations as x I y, where 
x e a and y e ft. For a given y, the class of couples we obtain is I y"a, which 
is similar to a; and the number of such classes, for varying y, is Nc'/S. Thus 
we have Nc'ft classes of Nc'a couples, and ft x a is the logical sum of these 
classes of couples. The class of such classes as ^ y"a, where y eft, is important 
again in connection with exponentiation; we have ^ y"a = a 4 y, whence the 
class of such classes, when y is varied among the ft's, is al "ft, and 
ftxa=s'al"ft (cf.*40-7), 
which we take as the definition of ft x a. 
We represent the arithmetical product of fi and v by /j, x0v. This, as well 
as Nc'a x0Nc'/S, is defined in terms of a x ft exactly as, in *110, the sum was 
defined in terms of a + ft. 
The present number contains many propositions which belong to the theory 
of a I "ft rather than (specially) of ft x a; and many propositions are rather 
logical than arithmetical in their nature, i.e. they might have been given in 
#55. The line is, however, so hard to draw that it has seemed better to deal 
simultaneously with all propositions on a I "ft or on its sum, which is ft x a. 
Thus in the present number, the early propositions, down to #113-118, deal 
mainly with logical properties of a 1 "ft and ft x a; the following propositions, 
* We define this as £ x o, rather than axft for the sake of certain analogies with products in 
relation-arithmetic Of. *166. 

102 CARDINAL ARITHMETIC [PART III 
down to #11313, deal mainly with arithmetical properties of a J, "ft', the  
propositions #113-14—"191 are concerned mainly with arithmetical properties of 
ft x a; #1132—-27 deal with the simpler properties of /j. x0 v\ #1133—-34 give 
propositions involving the multiplicative axiom, and exhibiting the connection 
(assuming this axiom) of addition and multiplication; #1134—'491 are  
concerned with various forms of the distributive law; #1135—'541 deal with the 
associative law of multiplication, and the remaining propositions deal with 
multiplication by 0 or 1 or 2. 
The most important propositions in the present number are the following: 
*113'101. h : R e ft x a . = . (a#, y).xea.yeft.R = x\,y 
This merely embodies the definition of /9 x a. 
#113105. I-: g'. a. D. a i e 1 -► 1 
This proposition is especially useful in dealing with exponentiation (#116). 
«113114 h :. a = A.v./3 = A: = ./Sxa = A 
It is in virtue of this proposition that a product of a finite number of factors 
only vanishes when one of its factors vanishes. 
#113118. I-. s'D"(/3 x a) C a. s'd"(/3 x a) C /3 
This proposition is chiefly useful in the analogous theory of ordinal products 
(#165, #166), where it enables us to apply #74-773. Unless ft = A, we have 
s'D"(j3xb) = b, and unless a = A, s'd"(ft x a) = ft (#113116). 
#11312. h : g! a. D. a ^ "jQ e Nc'/8 « CI excl'Nc'a 
I.e. unless a is null, a 4 "/S consists of Nc'/S mutually exclusive classes each 
having Nc'a members. 
#113127. h: R\-ryeasmry.S\-Be0am8.'D. 
(R || S) [ (8 x 7) e (a I "£) sm sm (7 I "8) 
This is an important proposition, since it gives a double correlator of a 4 "ft 
with 71 "B whenever simple correlators of a with 7 and of ft with B are given. 
It leads at once to 
#11313. I-: a sm 7. ft sm 8 . D . a i "ft sm sm 71 "8. (ft x a) sm (8 x 7) 
This proposition is fundamental in the theory of multiplication, since it 
shows that the number of members of ft x a depends only upon the numbers 
of members of a and ft. It is also fundamental in the theory of exponentiation, 
as will appear in #116. 
#113141. I-. Nc'(« x ft) = Nc'(/3 x a) 
This is the source of the commutative law of multiplication (#113-27). 
#113146. l-ia^/S.D.aXjQsm e4'(i'a w i'ft) 
This connects our present theory of multiplication with the theory of 
selections. 

SECTION B] ON THE ARITHMETICAL PRODUCT OF TWO CLASSES 103 
We come next to propositions concerning fi x0v. We have 
*113204. 1- :./11 = A. v.i> = A. v. ~(/i, v eNC): D. [ixav = A 
The use of this proposition, like that of *110"4, is for avoiding trivial 
exceptions. 
*11323. |-./ux0i>eNC 
*113-25. I-. Nc'7 x0 Nc'S = Nc'(7 x 8) 
This proposition enables us to infer propositions on products of cardinals 
from propositions on products of classes, and is therefore constantly used. 
*113'27. V .fj,xev = v x0/li 
This is the commutative law of cardinal multiplication. 
The chief proposition using the multiplicative axiom is 
#113*31. h :. Mult ax. D : /a,veNC ./cevn Cl'fi. D . 2'*-e/ix0v 
I.e. assuming the multiplicative axiom, the sum of the numbers of members 
in v classes of fx terms is fi x0v. If we had taken this sum as defining fix0v 
almost all propositions on multiplication would have required the  
multiplicative axiom. The advantage of a I "ft is that, given a sm 7 and ft sm 8, we can 
construct a double correlator of a 4 "ft with 71 "8, without using the  
multiplicative axiom. This is proved in *113127 (mentioned above). 
The distributive law, which is next considered, has various forms. We 
have, to begin with, 
*113*4. h . (ft v 7) x a = (ft x a) w (7 x a) 
whence, using also the commutative law, we easily deduce 
*113*43. h . (v +0 vs) X0 /J. = fi X0 (v +0 m) = (fi Xe v) +0 (/u X0 rs) 
But the distributive law also holds when, instead of enumerated summands 
ft, 7 or v, or, the suinmands are given as the members of a class k, which may 
be infinite. We have 
*113*48. 1-. s'a x "k = a x s'K = Cnv"{(s'/c) x a} 
whence, using the definitions of #112, we find 
*113*491. h : k e Clsa excl. D . SNc'a x"k = Nc'(a x2'«) = Ne'e* xc SNc'* 
This is an extension of the distributive law to the case where the number 
of summands may be infinite. 
The associative law 
«113*54. V.(fi xav) x0is = fixa(v x0 or) 
is proved without any difficulty. 
We prove next that fx xov = 0 when, and only when, /i = 0 or i> = 0, fi, v 
being existent cardinals (*113*602)*, that a cardinal is unchanged when it 
is multiplied by 1 (*113*62*621); that fj, x0 2 = fi +0 ^ (*113*66) and that 
fi x0(v +01)=(^ x0v) +o/j,(*113-671).

#113-671. r-./*xfl(i>+ol) = 0*xo!»)+,,* [#113-67-205.#110-4] 

#114. THE ARITHMETICAL PRODUCT OF A CLASS 
OF CLASSES 
Summary o/#114. 
The kind of multiplication defined in #113 cannot be extended beyond a 
finite number of factors. We therefore, as in the case of addition, introduce 
another definition, defining the product of the numbers of a class of classes, 
and capable of being applied to an infinite number of factors. We define the 
product of the numbers of members of * as Nc'eA'«; thus we put 
nNc'^Nc'e/* Df. 
It is to be observed that nNc'« is not a function of Nc"«, because, if two 
members of * have the same number, this will count only once in Nc"«, but 
will count twice in IINc'*. 
It is very easy to see that, in case k is finite, Nc'eA'« will be what we 
should ordinarily regard as the product of the numbers of members of *. For 
suppose (e.g.) 
K = I'a V I'ft V l'ry, 
where a =)=/9 . a 4= 7 •/S + 7' Then 
e&K = R {(gpc, y, z).R = oclavjyl@vzly.xea.ye/3.ze>y}. 
Thus if R is a member of 6*'*, R is determinate when x, y, z are given, x, y, z 
being the referents to a, /9,7. Whether a, £,7 overlap or not, the choice of any 
one of x, y, z is entirely independent of the choice of the other two, and  
therefore the total number of choices possible is obviously the product of the numbers 
of a, 0,7. Thus our definition will not conflict with what is commonly  
understood by a product. 
The propositions of this number are less numerous and less important than 
those of #113. We shall deal first with products of a single factor, and products 
in which one factor is null (#114-2—-27). We shall then deal (*114'3—'36) 
with the relations between the sort of multiplication here defined and the sort 
defined in #113. Then we have a few propositions (#1144—'43) showing that 
unit factors make no difference to the value of a product. Then we prove 
(#114'5—'52) that the value of the product is the same for two classes having 
double similarity, and then (#114-53—-571) we give extensions of this result 
which depend upon the multiplicative axiom. Finally, we give some new 
forms of the associative law of multiplication. 
Among the more important propositions in this number are the following: 
#114-21. h . nNc't'a - Nc'a 
I.e. a product of one factor is equal to that factor. 

120 CARDINAL ARITHMETIC [PART III 
T 
#11423. hAe«.D. IINc'* = 0 
I.e. a product vanishes if one of its factors is zero. The converse requires 
the multiplicative axiom, as appears from the proposition 
#114-26. V :. Mult ax. = : IlNc'/e = 0 . =,. A e k 
I.e. the multiplicative axiom is equivalent to the assumption that a product 
vanishes when, and only when, one of its factors is zero. 
#114301. h«nX=A.D. 6a'(* v X) sm ea'/e x eA'X 
whence 
#114 31. V : k n X = A . D. IINc'* x0 IINc'X = IINc'(* w X) 
which is a form of the associative law, and 
#11435. h : a + /8. D . IlNc'(t'a w i'0) = Nc'a x0 Nc'£ 
which connects the two sorts of multiplication. 
#11441. h:\Cl.D. IlNc'(* uX) = IlNc'« 
I.e. unit factors make no difference to the value of a product. 
#11451. I-: T[ s'X ek sm sm X. D . (T|| Te) [ e^'X e (eA'«) sm (eA'X) 
This proposition gives a correlator of e^'ic and e*'X as a function of a double 
correlator of k and X, and thus leads to 
#11452. h : « sm sm X. D . IINc'/e = IINc'X. eA'« sm e*'X 
Hence, by the propositions of #111, we infer 
#114571. V :. Mult ax. D: ^, v e NC . k, X e p n CYv . D . IlNc'* = nNc'X 
I.e. assuming the multiplicative axiom, if * and X each consist of p classes 
of v terms each, their products are equal. 
We have next various forms of the associative law, beginning with 
#114 6. V : k e Cls2 excl. D. IlNc'e^"* = IINc's'* 
which is an immediate consequence of *85'44. The other form is 
#114 632. r : S[ 7 e 1 -► 1. 7 C CL'S. 7 n S"y = A. D. 
eA'/2 {(a«) . a e 7. ^ = a x S'a} sm eA'(7 w $"7) 
As to the sense in which this is a form of the associative law, see the 
observations following #114'6. 
#114-01. IINc'* = Nc'eA'* Df 
#1141. r.IINc'* = Nc'eA'* [(#114-01)] 
#11411. h:^enNc'*.E.^sme/*.E.^eNcV« [#1141. #100-31] 
#114-12. h . eA'« e nNc'/e [»100'3. #1141] 
#114-2. h. nNc'A = 1 [#8315 . #101-2] 
Thus a product of no factors is 1. This is the source of /j? = 1, as we shall 
see later. 

SECTION B] THE ARITHMETICAL PRODUCT OF A CLASS OF CLASSES 121 
#11421. h . IINc't'a = Nc'a [*83'41] 
#11422. h.nNc'i'A = 0 [#11421. #1011] 
#11423. h:Ae«.D.nNc'/e = 0 [#83-11 .#101-1] 
Thus an arithmetical product is zero if any of its factors is zero. To prove 
the converse, we have to assum6 the multiplicative axiom, which, in fact, is 
equivalent to the proposition that an arithmetical product is only zero when 
at least one of its factors is zero.

#114-6. h : k e Cls2 excl. D . nNc'e/'* = IINcV/c [*85'44] 
This is the most general form of the associative law for arithmetical  
multiplication. 
Owing to the fact that we have two kinds of multiplication, namely 
a x /9 and 6a'*, we have four forms of the associative law of multiplication, 
namely: 
(1) #114'6, above, 
(2) #113-54, i.e. h . (y x0 v) x0 ts = p x0 (v x0 ts), 
(3) #114-31, i.e. h«nX = A.D. IINc'* x0nNc'X = nNc'(/c wX), 
(4) a form of the associative law which has not yet been proved, which 
may be explained as follows. 
Suppose we have a number of pairs of classes, e.g. (a,, /9,), (cr2) &)» 
(¾./Ss); ■ ■ • • Suppose we form the products a, x/9,, a2X/82, orsX/S3,... and 
multiply all these products together. We wish to prove that (with a suitable 
hypothesis) the result is similar to the product of all the a's and all the /Q's 
taken together as one class; i.e. if we call X the class of products a, x /9,, a2 x /92, 
0¾ x /Ss,..., and fi the class whose members are or,, 0¼. a3,..., /9,, /S2, /¾. ••■> we 
wish to prove 
nNc'x =nNc'/u. 
In order to express this proposition in symbols, let S be the correlator of the 
a's and £'s, so that #„ = S'av. (The suffix v will not be used further, since it 
implies that the number of a's and of /9's is finite or denumerable.) Then our 
class of products of the form a x /9 is 
P- Kaa) • a e 7. /li = a x S'a], 

SECTION B] THE ARITHMETICAL PRODUCT OF A CLASS OF CLASSES 125 
where 7 is the class of all the as; and the product of this class of products is 
e*'p, {(ga) . a e 7. ft, = a x S'a\. 
On the other hand, the class of all the a's and @'s is 7 w #"7, and the product 
of this class is 
Thus what we have to prove (with a suitable hypothesis) is 
eSp. {(ga) . a e 7. p = a x S'a] sra 6^(7 w S"y). 
The hypothesis required is 
8 [ 7 e 1 -► 1.7 C CL'S. 7 n S"y = A. 
A smaller hypothesis suffices, however, for a proposition which, in virtue of 
*114'301, is closely allied to the above, namely 
6a'7 x e*'S"ry sm etjl {(ga) . a e 7 . fi = a x S'a}. 
For this, a sufficient hypothesis is 
Styel->l.yCCL'S. 
Thus e.g. we may write I for S, and we find 
I-. e&'y x eA'7 sm e&'p. {(ga). a e 7 . p = a x a}. 
We shall now prove the above propositions. What follows, down to 
*114"621, consists of lemmas. 
For convenience, we write Sx'a for a x S'a in the course of these lemmas; 
this notation is introduced in the hypotheses of the lemmas.

R&W II 
9 

*115. MULTIPLICATIVE CLASSES AND ARITHMETICAL CLASSES 
Summary o/*115. 
Whenever * is a class of mutually exclusive classes, eA'« is similar to 
D"ea'/e; hence 
IINc'/t = Nc'D"eA'«. 
Now D"ei'* is of the same type as k; and when k is a class of mutually 
exclusive classes, D"eA'/e consists of all classes formed by selecting one  
representative from each member of k. It often happens that D"ea'/e is easier to 
deal with than 6*'*; hence when possible {i.e. when «e Cls2 excl), it is  
convenient to use D"ea'/e, rather than e&'ic, as the standard member of IlNc'/e. 
*We therefore put 
Prod'*=D"eA'« Df. 
We shall call Prod'/e the "multiplicative class" of*. 
The associative law, 
Prod V/e sm Prod'Prod"*, 
requires not merely k e Cls2 excl, but also s'k e Cls2 excl. The combination of 
these two hypotheses gives a completely disjointed class of classes of classes, 
ie. a class of classes of classes k which can be obtained by dividing a given 
class (s's'k) into mutually exclusive portions, and then dividing each of those 
portions into mutually exclusive portions. For example, take a square (a class 
of points) and divide it by horizontal lines, and then divide each of the  
resulting rectangles by vertical lines; then the resulting rows of little rectangles 
form such a class, each row of rectangles being one member of the class. 
Such a class we call an "arithmetical" class, and denote by "Cls'arithm." 
The present number is concerned with the properties of multiplicative 
classes and arithmetical classes. Some of these properties will be useful in 
dealing with exponentiation. 
The present number begins with various propositions concerning Prod'* 
which are merely repetitions of previous propositions of *83, *84, *85 or *113. 
Thus we have 
#116141. l-:g!Prod'*.:>.s'Prod'* = s'* by *83'66, 
*115142. h.Prod't'a = i"a by *83-7, 
*115143. I-. ProdVa = t'a by *83-7l, 
*11516. h . k e Cls2 excl. Z>. Prod'* C Nc'/c by *100-64, 
and various other properties. 

SECTION B] MULTIPLICATIVE CLASSES AND ARITHMETICAL CLASSES 131 
We then proceed to consider Cls'arithm. We prove 
*115-22. r- :./eeCls'arithm.D :s"KeCls2excl:a,,S eK.'gLlslans'^.'^a^.a=^ 
and *115-23 gives a similar proposition substituting " Prod " for s. 
After a few more propositions on Cls'arithm, we proceed to the associative 
law for Prod (*115-34), i.e. 
\-:/ce Cls'arithm . D. Prod'Prod"* sm Prod's'/e. 
(This proposition, *115-34, also states that, with the same hypothesis, 
Prod's'/e sm ea's'k.) Hence we have 
*115-35. h: /eeCls'arithm.D . Nc'Prod'Prod"* = Nc'Prod V* = IlNc'Prod"/e 
= IINc'ei"* = IlNc's'* 
We have also 
*115-42. h :*eClssarithm.:>.Prod'Prod"« = D'"Prod'eA"* = D'"D"eA'eA"* 
*115-44. h: /eeCls'arithm. D. Prod V/c = s "Prod 'Prod"* 
We have next to prove that if two classes of classes have double similarity, 
so have their multiplicative classes. The proof is simple, since the double 
correlator is the same as for the original classes, i.e. 
*115-502. h : Tfs'X e* smsm X. D. Tfs'Prod'X e(Prod'«) sm sm(Prod'X) 
whence 
*115-51. h : * sm sm X. D. Prod'* sm sm Prod'X

and are analogous to them. One of these is used in the following number 
in proving fi" x0 vm = (fi x0 v)m, namely, 
*115-6. V \(B?WR,8\i*\ -»1.7Ca'JS.7Ca'S.iJ"7,S"7eCl8!!excl.O.

" a, /9 e k . g ! s'a a «'£ . D0i/I . a = (9," 
the converse implication does not hold. If there were two different classes 
a and ft having the same sum, we might have gls'aAs'yS, i.e. gls'a, without 
having a = /9, in spite of "s"k e Cls2 excl." In proofs, less use can be made 
of "s"*e Cls2 excl" than of "a,/9 e k . ft ! s'a a s'0 O«,0 . a = /3." If A~e * 
or i'A~e«, the latter implies s[/c e 1—*► 1.

[#115-660112] 

#116. EXPONENTIATION 
Summary o/*116. 
In this number, we define "aexp/3," meaning "a to the exponent ft,' 
where a and ft are classes, as 
Prod'a I "ft. 
Now Prod'a 4 "ft consists of all ways of selecting one each from the members 
of a I "/3, i.e. from the classes ly"a, where ye ft. Thus to get a member of 
Prod'a I "ft, take a set of couples x \, y, where x is always an a, and there is 
only one x for a given y, and y is each member of ft in succession. Thus for 
each member of ft, we have Nc'a possible referents; hence it is plain that the 
number of possible sets of couples consists of Nc'/S factors each equal to Nc'a, 
and is therefore fit to be taken as defining (Nc'a)Nc'^. 
The definitions of /j," and (Nc'a)Nc<^ are derived from the definition of 
a exp ft exactly as the definitions of /x +0 v and Nc'a +c Nc'/S, or of \x, x0 v and 
Nc'a x0 Nc'/S, were derived respectively from a + ft and a x ft. 
The chief difficulty in this number lies in the proof of the three formal 
laws of exponentiation, namely 
/l"X0/^ = /^+^, 
fiv x0 vm = (p x0 vy, 
and {fjiv)v = fjbvX,}m. 
The proofs of the second and third of these, in particular, require various 
lemmas; but there is no difficulty involved except the complexity of the 
classes and relations concerned. 
The definition of /*" is so framed as to minimize the necessity for the 
multiplicative axiom (see the note on #11331 in the introduction to #113). 
We have 
#11636. V :. Mult ax . D : p,v e NC - t'A . * e v n Cl'/u . D . IINc'/e = /u» 
that is, assuming the multiplicative axiom, the product of v factors each 
equal to fx is p" (assuming p and v to be cardinals which are not null). 
If we had defined fi" as the product of v factors each equal to p, we should 
have required the multiplicative axiom for almost all propositions on p"; but 
by taking the particular class a J, "ft, we avoid the multiplicative axiom 
except in a few propositions. Among these few is the above proposition 
connecting exponentiation with multiplication. 
Cantor has defined fi" by means of the class of " Belegungen," i.e. the 
class 
R (R e 1 -> Cls . D'fl C a . Q'iJ = ft) 

SECTION b] exponentiation 139 
which (#11612) = (a f ft)Sft. By #85-53 and #113-103, this class is equal to 
^"(aexpjQ) (as is proved in #11613), whence, since s[a exp^e 1 —► 1, it 
follows (#116'15) that the class of "Belegungen" is similar to aexp/3. 
Hence our definition gives the same value of /j/ as Cantor's. 
The propositions of the present number begin with various simple 
properties of a exp ft. Its existence follows from 
#116152. h : x e a. D. x \ "ft e (a exp ft) 
whence (#11616) h . Cnv'"/31 "a C a exp ft, and 
#116-18. h:.a!a.v./S = A: = .glaexp^ 
We have 
#116 19. I-: a sm 7. ft sm 8. D . (a exp ft) sm sm (7 exp B) 
in virtue of #11313 and #11551. #116192 shows that, if R[y correlates 
a with 7, and S[8 correlates ft with 8, then (R\\ S)[ (8 x 7) is a double 
correlator of (a exp ft) with (7 exp 8). 
We then proceed to a set of propositions on p*, which are analogous to 
#1132 ff. on /li xev. We have 
#116-203. h : g! p'. D . y,, ve NC - t'A . y, v e N0C 
#116-25. 1-.^7)^=^(7 exp 8) 
and various other less useful propositions. 
We then have various propositions on 0 and 1 and 2. We prove 
#116-301. hi^eNC-t'A.3.^ = 1 
#116-311. h:i>eNC-i'A-i'0.D.0" = 0 
#116-321. h : y, e NC - t'A . D . fi1 = sm"/* 
(Observe that sm"/i is the same cardinal as fi, but rendered typically 
ambiguous.) 
#116-331. h:AieNC-i'A.D.l'1=l 
#116-34. \-.fS = fi xefi 
(This proposition does not require that y should be a cardinal.) 
After the proposition (#116-36) already quoted, on the connection of 
exponentiation and multiplication, we proceed to a set of propositions on 
the case where a number of classes are all given as similar (by assignable 
correlations) to a given class. In *116-411, we prove that if * is a class 
of mutually exclusive classes, each of which is similar to a given class 7, 
and if, when ae/c,M'a is a correlator of a and 7, and T is the sum of M"k, 
then 
Nc'e^'3^'7 = Nc'2V7 = Nc'(* exp 7) = (Nc'*)No'r. 

140 CARDINAL ARITHMETIC [PART III 
This is a further connection of multiplication and exponentiation. (On the 
purport of this and following propositions, see the explanation preceding 
#116-4.) In #11643, the hypothesis is somewhat modified. We still have a 
set * of classes which are all similar to 7, but the correlator for a given class 
a is not given as M'a, but is given as M'w, where w is a member of a class 8 
which is similar to k. Then k = D"M"8. We assume that M \ 8 is a one-one, 
and that if M'w and M'v have domains which overlap, then w = v. Thus * is 
a class of mutually exclusive classes, each of which has Nc'7 terms, while 
* has Nc'8 terms. Then it is proved in *116"43 that 
Prod'D"Jf"8 sm sm (7 exp 8). IINc'D"Jl/"8 = (Nc'7)N0's. 
This proposition and another (#11645) which follows from it are useful in 
proving the formal laws of exponentiation. The proof of these occupies the 
following propositions from #1165 to #11668. We have 
#116-52. h . /x" x0 n" = fi*+" 
#11655. K^x,i^ = (|jx,i-)s 
#116-63. 1-.^-^^ = (^-)^ 
An extension of the first of these is 
#116-661. h . IINc'(a exp)"/e = (Nc'a)SNo'' 
Here the number of members of k need not be finite. The purport of the 
proposition is as follows: Let /3, 7, 8, ... be the members of k\ form aexp/S, 
a exp 7, a exp B, ..., and take the product of the numbers of all these; then 
the resulting number is the same as if we first took the sum of the numbers 
of all the members of *, thus obtaining (say) a number fi, and raised Nc'a to 
the /nth power. 
An extension of #11655 is given by#11668, where we prove 
Y-.KeCls= excl. :>. IINc'exp7"* = (IINc'*)N<!'r. 
There is no analogous extension of #11663. 
We prove next Cantor's proposition (which is very useful) 
#116-72. V . Nc'Cl'a = 2Nc'« 
I.e. the number of combinations of fx things any number at a time is 2". 
(Observe that /x need not be finite.) The remainder of the number is  
concerned with consequences of this proposition. 
#11601. a exp £ = Prod'a I "@ Df

#116-321. h:/LieNC-i'A.D./L<,1 = sm"/Ll, [#116-32] 
It would not be an error to write "fi1 = fi" instead of "fj} = sm"/Li" in the 
above proposition. For if the " sm" is typically determined so that sm"^ e t'/j,, 
then sm"/Li = /Li, Thus in virtue of #116-321, m1 = /li is true whenever it is 
significant. But the above form gives more information, since it preserves 
the typical ambiguity of /j} and sm"/u,.

The above proposition connects exponentiation with multiplication.

figure, in which, for the sake of simplicity, all the classes concerned are taken 
to be finite. 
Let * be a set of classes, constituted by four rows of five dots in the 
figure, which are each given as similar to a given class 7, represented by the 
top row of five dots in the figure, namely the row enclosed in an oval. We 
assume that an actual correlating relation is given correlating each member 
of k with 7. Let X be the class of these relations, and assume that X consists 
of one correlator for each member of *, and that *eCls2excl. Thus D"X = «, 
and Re\. 5.Q.'R= 7. Put T = s'\. Then, if «67, T relates to z every 
member of the column below z, i.e. T'z consists of the four dots which are 
vertically below z; assuming, what in the circumstances is possible, that each 
dot is placed below its correlate in 7. Thus T"y represents the columns, 
while D"X represents the rows. 
We prove, in «116*41, that 2**7» ^e class °f rows, has double similarity 
with X1 "7, or, what comes to the same thing, with k I "7. Hence it follows 
that T"y, which is the whole class of dots, is similar to 7 x X or 7 x k, and 
that Nc'ea'T'fy which is the product of the numbers of the columns, is equal 
10—2 

148 CARDINAL ARITHMETIC [PART III 
to (Nc'X)No'v or (Nc'/c)No'r. The correlator which is used for proving these 
propositions is W, where, if R is a member of X and z is a member of 7, W 
correlates R'z with R ^ z. 
Similarly, by correlating R'z with z \ R, calling the correlator U, we 
have U" I R"y = R"y, i.e. Ue'y 1R= V'R, whence Ue"y 1 "X = D"X. Hence 
D"X, i.e. the class of rows, has double similarity with 71 "X or 7 I "it, whence 
the product of the numbers of the rows is (Nc^)1*0'* or (Nc^y)1*0'*. 
Finally, we take a class 8 similar to k or X (illustrated in the figure by 
the column of dots enclosed in an oval), and calling M a correlator of X and 8, 
we replace X by M"8 and k by B"M"8. We thus find that, if M \ 8  
correlates with 8 a class of relations whose domains are mutually exclusive, and 
which each correlate their domains with a given class 7, then T>"M"B has 
double similarity with 71 "8, whence the same results as before with 8 in 
place of k or X. 
The following propositions are useful in connecting multiplication with 
exponentiation, and in proving the formal laws of exponentiation.

This completes the proof of the second of the formal laws of exponentiation. 
The following propositions are lemmas for the third of these laws, namely

*117. GREATER AND LESS 
Summary o/*ll7. 
A cardinal fx. is said to be greater than another cardinal v when there is 
a class a which has /x, terms and has a part which has v terms, while there is 
no class fH which has v terms and has a part which has fi terms. The relation 
"greater than" is transitive and asymmetrical; and by the SchrSder-Bernstein 
theorem, if p is greater than or equal to v, and v is greater than or equal to 
fi,, then fi = v. But we cannot prove that of any two cardinals one must be 
the greater, unless we assume the multiplicative axiom. The proof then 
follows from Zermelo's theorem that on that assumption every class can be 
well-ordered. This subject will be dealt with at a later stage. 
The form of the definitions is so arranged as to allow of the inequality of 
two cardinals in different types. The relevant considerations are the same as 
for the definitions of addition, multiplication and exponentiation. 
Our definition of " p > v " is 
*117-01. fi>v. = . (ga, f3)-n = N0c'a. v = Noc'/S. 
3! Cl'a n Nc'£. ~ a ! Cl'jS n Nc'a Df 
We also define " p > Nc'a " as meaning " p > N0c'a," and " Nc'a > v " as 
meaning "N0c'a>i'," for the reasons explained in *110. It then easily 
follows that if /* > v, /j, and v must be homogeneous cardinals (this is part of 
*11715); that if fi and v are homogeneous cardinals, and n> v, the same 
holds if we substitute sm"/i and sm"K for one or both of fx and v (*ll7-16); 
that 
*11713. h : Nc'a > Nc'£. = . g ! Cl'a n Nc'/S .~3! Cl'/8 « Nc'a 
and that 
*11714 Yifi>v. = . (ga, £). y, = N0c'a. v = Noc'jS. Nc'a > Nc'/S 
We cannot define " p ^ v " as " p > v. v . p = v," because " p = v " restricts 
fx and v too much by requiring that they should be of the same type, and 
restricts them too little by not requiring that they should both be existent 
cardinals. To avoid both these inconveniences, we put 
*ll7-05. /j,^v. = :fi>v.v.tj,>ve N0C . /a = sn>"" Df 
The use of this definition is chiefly through the propositions 
*117108. r :. Nc'a > Nc'£. = : Nc'a > Nc'/9. v . Nc'a = Nc'£ 
*H7-24 I-: y,>v. = .(aa,0)./* = Noc'o . » = Noc'/9. Nc'a>Nc'/3 

166 CARDINAL ARITHMETIC [PART III 
t 
In *ll7-2, we repeat the Schroder-Bernstein theorem (#73-88), which is 
required in most of the remaining- propositions of this number. It leads at 
once to the propositions 
*117-22. h : a I Cl'a n Nc'£ . = . Nc'a > Nc'£ 
(which practically supersedes the definition of " ^ ") 
*117-221. h : Nc'a > Nc'£. = . (gp). p C a . p sm /3 
*117222. hijSCa.D.Nc'a^Nc'/S 
*117-23. h : Nc'a > Nc'£. Nc'£ > Nc'a. = . Nc'a = Nc'£ 
This last proposition may be called the Schroder-Bernstein theorem with 
as much propriety as *73-88; the two are scarcely different. 
If we now revert to the definition of /j. > v, or to *ll7-13, and apply 
*H7-22, we see (*ll7-26) that "Nc'a>Nc'/S" may be conveniently regarded 
as asserting Nc'a^Nc',8.~(Nc'/S^Nc'a); in fact, the best ideas to work 
with are ^ and its converse ^, which for practical purposes we regard as 
defined by *117 "22, and from which we derive > and <. The relation > 
will be the product of ^ into the negation of its converse; this holds for ft, 
and v (*117-281) as well as for Nc'a and Nc',9. 
*117-331 constitute an important use of *110"72, namely to prove that 
one existent cardinal is greater than another or equal to it when the first can 
be obtained by adding to the second (where what is added must be a cardinal). 
That is to say, we have 
*117-3. h : Nc'a > Nc'£. = . (go) .oeNC. Nc'a = Nc'/3 +„ ts 
*117-31. \-:.fi^v. = :fj,,ve N0C : (gor). is e NC . p = v +0 is 
*ll7-4—-47l are concerned in proving that > and ^ are transitive, that 
> is asymmetrical (*ll7-42), and allied propositions. 
Our next set of propositions is concerned with 0 and 1 and 2. We prove 
that a homogeneous cardinal is whatever is greater than or equal to 0 
(*117-501); that a homogeneous cardinal other than 0 is whatever is greater 
than 0 (*117-511) ; that a homogeneous cardinal other than 0 is whatever is 
greater than or equal to 1 (*117-531); and that a homogeneous cardinal 
other than 0 and 1 is whatever is greater than 1 (*117"55), and is whatever 
is greater than or equal to 2 (*117-551). 
We next prove a set of propositions concerning J? which have no analogues 
for >, except when the cardinals concerned are finite. Thus e.g. we prove 
*117561. r-:p> v . xss e N0C . D . /i +0 ts ^ v +c or 
If we substitute > for ^, this no longer holds. Thus e.g. put /j, = 2, v = 1, 
vr = K0 (cf. *123); then fx~> v, but /j,+cts = v+0ts = is. Similar remarks 
apply to the analogous propositions (*117,571,581,591) on multiplication and 
exponentiation. 

SECTION B] 
GREATER AND LESS 
167 
We prove next that a sum is greater than or equal to either of its sum- 
mands (*ll7-6); that a product neither of whose factors vanishes is greater 
than or equal to either of its factors (*ll7-62); that, assuming fx and v are 
existent cardinals, then if they are neither 0 nor 1, their product is greater 
than or equal to their sum (#117-631), and if fx is neither 0 nor 1, then 
^^^0^117-652). 
The last important proposition in this number is Cantor's theorem 
#117661. h : y e N0C . D . 2" > ^ 
which follows immediately from *l02-72 and *116-72. 
The propositions of this number are much used in the following section, 
on finite and infinite.

GENERAL NOTE ON CARDINAL CORRELATORS 
The correlators established at various stages throughout Section B present 
certain analogies to each other, and they or others closely resembling them 
will be found to be the correlators required in relation-arithmetic (Part IV). 
We shall therefore here collect together the most important propositions 
hitherto proved on correlators. 
When we have to deal with correlators of two different functions of a 
single class, as e.g. e&'/c and Prod'tf, the correlator is usually D or s or s | D, 
with a suitable limitation on the converse domain. Sometimes it is i | D or 
e | D. Thus for example the class e J "*, by means of which 2'* is defined 
(#112), has double similarity with k if at eCls2excl(#112-14<); in this case, the 
double correlator is I | D with its converse domain limited, i.e. 
V : *e Cls2 excl. D . I jDfS'* ear smsm(e J"k). 
In the case of Prod'* and e\K, the correlator is D, i.e. 
V : k e Cls2 excl. D . D [ e*'/c e (Prod'*) §55 (eA'*). 
In the case of 6a's'k and e^'e^'x, the correlator is s | D, i.e. 
h : k e Cls2 excl. D . s | D [ e*'e±"/c e (eA's'«) sm (ed'e.i"*). 
s|D also correlates e^'tf with eA'eJ"^ (#85-61) and iV« with e\'P1"a 
(#85-53), and PAV* with ed'iV'* (#85-27-42) if * e Cls2 excl. 
The correlator of (a | /S)a'/S with (a exp £) is s (#116-131). 
Another kind of correlator arises where we are given a correlator of /e and 
X, and we wish to construct a correlator for some associated classes W'/e and 
W'\ or where we are given correlators of a with y and of /S with 8, and we 
wish to construct a correlator of a $ /9 with 7 $ 8, where $ is some double 
descriptive function in the sense of #38. In this case, the correlator will 
usually be of the form R j| S (with a limited converse domain). Sometimes 
R and S will be identical; sometimes S will be Re. Such correlators always 
depend upon 
#55-61. r : E ! R'x . E ! S'y. D . (R || 8)l(a ly) = (R'x) I (S'y) 
together with the propositions #74-77 seq. giving cases in which (JS|| S)\~ X is 
a one-one relation. It follows from #55-61 that if R and S are correlators 
whose converse domains include the domain and converse domain respectively 
of a relation P, then (R\\S)'P will be a relation holding between R'x and 
S'y whenever P holds between x and y. Examples of such correlators as 
R\\S are 
#112153. \-iTeKSm-Bm\.0.(T\\Tt)[s'el't\e(elltK)SmSm(el"\) 
12—2

immediate consequence of #113'127 and #115"502, since 
a exp £ = Prod'a 4 "# and s'Prod'7 4 "8 = 8 x 7. 
In order to develop the subject, it is almost always necessary, not merely 
to prove that two classes are similar, but actually to construct a correlator 
of the two classes. This applies equally to relation-arithmetic, in which 
analogous correlators are used to prove ordinal similarity. 

SECTION C 
FINITE AND INFINITE 
Summary of Section C. 
The distinction of finite and infinite is not required, as appears from 
Section B, for the definition of the arithmetical operations or for the proof of 
their formal laws. There are, however, many important respects in which 
finite cardinals and classes differ respectively from infinite cardinals and 
classes, and these differences must now be investigated. 
There are two different ways in which we may define the finite and the 
infinite, and these two ways cannot (so far as is known at present) be shown 
to be equivalent except by assuming the multiplicative axiom. As there 
seems no good reason for regarding one of these ways as giving more exactly 
than the other what is usually meant by the words " finite" and " infinite," 
we shall, to avoid confusion, give other names than these to each of the two 
ways of dividing classes and cardinals. The division effected by the first 
method of definition we shall call the division into inductive and non-inductive; 
that effected by the second method we shall call the division into non-reflexive 
and reflexive. 
The division into inductive and non-inductive, which is treated in #120, is 
defined as follows. An inductive cardinal is one which can be reached from 0 
by successive additions of 1; that is, an inductive cardinal is one which has to 
0 the relation (+01)^, where (by *38'02) +01 is the relation of a +„ 1 to a, and 
the subscript asterisk has the meaning defined in #90. Hence we put 
NC induct = 6 {a (+ol)*0J M 
By applying the definition of #90, this gives 
I-:: a eNC induct .= :. % e p . Df. f +„ 1 e/i: Oe/x: D^.ae^. 
This proposition may be regarded as stating that an inductive cardinal is 
one which obeys mathematical induction starting from 0, i.e. it is one which 
possesses every property possessed by 0 and by the numbers obtained by 
adding 1 to numbers possessing the property. In elementary mathematics, 
it is customary to regard mathematical induction, as applied to the series of 
natural numbers, as a principle rather than a definition, but according to 

182 CARDINAL ARITHMETIC [PART III 
the above procedure it becomes a definition rather than a principle. This 
procedure is unavoidable as soon as it is perceived that there are cardinals 
which do not obey mathematical induction starting from 0. (This only holds 
on the assumption that the total number of objects in any one type is not 
one of the inductive cardinals. This assumption, in a slightly different form, 
is introduced below as the " axiom of infinity.") Thus for example 0 4= 1. and 
£4= f +0 1 ■ D . f +01 =(= f +0 2. Hence if a is any inductive cardinal, a 4= « +0 1- 
But we know that N0, the first of Cantor's transfinite cardinals*, satisfies 
N0 = N0 +0 1. Thus mathematical induction starting from 0 cannot be validly 
applied to prove properties of N0. It follows that the inductive cardinals as 
above defined are only some among cardinals; nor does it appear that there 
is any way of defining them except as those that obey mathematical induction 
starting from 0. It follows that mathematical induction is not a principle, to 
be either proved or assumed as an axiom, but is merely a characteristic 
defining a certain class of cardinals, namely the class of inductive cardinals. 
By a syllogism in Barbara, it is evident that 0 is an inductive cardinal; 
hence by the definition 1 is an inductive cardinal, and hence 2, 3, ... are 
inductive cardinals. Thus any given cardinal in the series of natural numbers 
can be shown to be an inductive cardinal. The usual elementary properties 
of inductive cardinals, such as the uniqueness? of subtraction and division, are 
easily proved by mathematical induction. 
We define an inductive class as a class the number of whose terms is an 
inductive cardinal. More simply, we put 
Cls induct = s'NC induct Df. 
It is then easily shown that an inductive class is one which can be reached 
from A by successive'additions of single members. That is, if we put 
4— 
then Cls induct = M^'A. 
Thus we have 
h :: p e Cls induct. = :. ?? e p,. D,, g,. ?? u 1'j/ e p,: A e p,: D^ . p e p,. 
We might equally well have begun by defining inductive classes, and  
proceeded to define inductive cardinals as the cardinals of inductive classes; in 
that case, we should have used the above relation M to define inductive 
classes. 
Some of the properties which we expect inductive cardinals to possess, 
such for example as a =)= a +01, can only be proved by assuming that no 
inductive cardinal is null, i.e. that 
a e NC induct. D„ . g ! a. 
This amounts to the assumption that, in any fixed type, a class can be found 
* For the definition of K0, cf. *123-01 and p. 186 of this summary. 

SECTION C] 
FINITE AND INFINITE 
183 
having any assigned inductive number of terms. If this were false, there 
would have to be some definite member of the Series of natural numbers 
which gave the total number of objects of the type in question. Thus suppose 
there were exactly n individuals in the universe, and no more, where n is an 
inductive cardinal. We should then have 2n classes, 22" classes of classes, and 
so on. In that case, in the type of individuals we should have n +0 1 = A, 
n +0 2 = A, etc. Hence we should have 
n +o 1 = (w +o 1) +o 1. etc. 
In the type of classes, we should get similar results for 2n, and so on. It is 
plain (though not demonstrable except in each particular case) that if the 
assumption a e NC induct. D„ ■ 3 ! a fails in any one type, it fails in any other 
type in the same hierarchy, and if it holds in any one, it holds in any other; 
for if n be the total number of individuals, then if n is an inductive cardinal, 
the total number of any other type is an inductive cardinal, while if n is not 
an inductive cardinal, no more is the total number of any other type. Hence 
the assumption a e NC induct. Da . g ! a is either true in any type or false in 
any type in one hierarchy. We shall call it the " axiom of infinity," putting 
Infin ax . = : a e NC induct. D„ . g ! a Df. 
This assumption, like the multiplicative axiom, will be adduced as a hypothesis 
whenever it is relevant. It seems plain that there is nothing in logic to  
necessitate its truth or falsehood, and that it can only be legitimately believed 
or disbelieved on empirical grounds. When we wish to use a typically definite 
form of the axiom, we shall employ the definition 
Infin ax (x). =: a e NC induct. Da . g I a (x) Df, 
which asserts that, if a is any inductive cardinal, there are at least a terms 
of the same type as x. 
It is important to observe that, although the axiom of infinity cannot 
(so far as appears) be proved a priori, we can prove that any given inductive 
cardinal exists in a sufficiently high type. For if the total number of individuals 
be n, the numbers of objects in succeeding types are 2", 22 , etc., and these 
numbers grow beyond any assigned inductive cardinal. Owing, however, to 
the fact that we cannot add together an infinite number of classes whose 
types increase without limit, we cannot hence show that there is a type in 
which every inductive cardinal exists, though we can show of every inductive 
cardinal that there is a type in which it exists. I.e. if a is any inductive 
cardinal, there must be a type for x such that g ! a (x) is true; but there need 
not be a type for x such that if a is any inductive cardinal, g ! a (x) is true. 
The axiom of infinity suffices to prove the existence, in appropriate types, 
of No, 2No, 22 °, ... N„ N2, ...*. It does not suffice, so far as we know, to prove 
* For the definitions of K,, K2, etc., see *265. 

184 CARDINAL ARITHMETIC [PART III 
the existence of Nu or any Aleph with a greater suffix than a>, because the 
existences of K,, N2, ... are proved in successively rising types, and no meaning 
can be found for a type whose order is infinite. 
The other definition of finite and infinite is of less importance in practice 
than the definition by induction. It is dealt with in #124. According to 
this definition, we call a class reflexive when it contains a proper part similar 
to itself, i.e. we put 
Cls refl = 5 {(a2J). R e 1 -►1. WR = a . d'R C a . (L'R =f a} Df, 
or, what comes to the same thing, 
Cls refl = a j(aiJ). A e 1 -»1. (L'R C D'iJ . g IB'R . a = B'R} Df. 
We call a cardinal reflexive when it is the homogeneous cardinal of a reflexive 
class, i.e. we put 
NC refl = N0c"Cls refl Df. 
It is easy to show that 
NCrefl = a{a!a.a = a+0l}. 
We find that inductive classes and cardinals are non-reflexive, and reflexive 
classes and cardinals are non-inductive. We find also that reflexive cardinals 
are those that are equal to or greater than tt0, while inductive cardinals are 
those that are less than N0. By assuming the multiplicative axiom, we can 
show that every cardinal is equal to, greater than, or less than N0, whence 
it follows that every cardinal is either reflexive or inductive, thus identifying 
the two definitions of finite and infinite. But so long as we refrain from 
assuming either the multiplicative axiom or some special axiom ad hoc, it 
remains possible (so far as is known at present) that there may be cardinals 
neither greater than, nor equal to, nor less than N0. Such cardinals, if they 
exist, are neither inductive nor reflexive: they are infinite if we define 
infinity by the negation of induction, but finite if we define infinity by 
reflexiveness. It is possible that further investigation may either prove or 
disprove the existence of such cardinals; for the present, their existence 
must remain an open question, except for those who regard the multiplicative 
axiom as a self-evident truth. 
In #121 we shall consider intervals in a discrete series; i.e. in a series 
generated by a one-one relation between consecutive terms. If P be the 
generating relation of such a series, and x and y be two members of the series, 
of which y is the later, the terms which lie between x and y are the terms z 
for which we have 
xP^z.zP^y, 
where P^ has the meaning defined in #91. Henpe we put 
P(*-2,) = P>^po'2/ Df, 
where "P(x — y)" means "the P-interval between x and y." We want also
